verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 1:1
verses.text: Book : In Which Tertullian Pursues His Argument.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 1:2
verses.text: Jesus is the Christ of the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 1:3
verses.text: He Derives His Proofs from St.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 1:4
verses.text: Luke's Gospel; That Being the Only Historical Portion of the New Testament Partially Accepted by Marcion.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 1:5
verses.text: This Book May Also Be Regarded as a Commentary on St.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 1:6
verses.text: Luke.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 1:7
verses.text: It Gives Remarkable Proof of Tertullian's Grasp of Scripture, and Proves that "The Old Testament is Not Contrary to the New".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 1:8
verses.text: It Also Abounds in Striking Expositions of Scriptural Passages, Embracing Profound Views of Revelation, in Connection with the Nature of Man.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 1:9
verses.text: Examination of the Antitheses of Marcion, Bringing Them to the Test of Marcion's Own Gospel.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 1:10
verses.text: Certain True Antitheses in the Dispensations of the Old and the New Testaments.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 1:11
verses.text: These Variations Quite Compatible with One and the Same God, Who Ordered Them.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 1:12
verses.text: Every opinion and the whole scheme of the impious and sacrilegious Marcion we now bring to the test of that very Gospel which, by his process of interpolation, he has made his own.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 1:13
verses.text: To encourage a belief of this Gospel he has actually devised for it a sort of dower, in a work composed of contrary statements set in opposition, thence entitled Antitheses, and compiled with a view to such a severance of the law from the gospel as should divide the Deity into two, nay, diverse, gods—one for each Instrument, or Testament as it is more usual to call it; that by such means he might also patronize belief in "the Gospel according to the Antitheses".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 1:14
verses.text: These, however, I would have attacked in special combat, hand to hand; that is to say, I would have encountered singly the several devices of the Pontic heretic, if it were not much more convenient to refute them in and with that very gospel to which they contribute their support.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 1:15
verses.text: Although it is so easy to meet them at once with a peremptory demurrer, yet, in order that I may both make them admissible in argument, and account them valid expressions of opinion, and even contend that they make for our side, that so there may be all the redder shame for the blindness of their author, we have now drawn out some antitheses of our own in opposition to Marcion.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 1:16
verses.text: And indeed I do allow that one order did run its course in the old dispensation under the Creator, and that another is on its way in the new under Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 1:17
verses.text: I do not deny that there is a difference in the language of their documents, in their precepts of virtue, and in their teachings of the law; but yet all this diversity is consistent with one and the same God, even Him by whom it was arranged and also foretold.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 1:18
verses.text: Long ago did Isaiah declare that "out of Sion should go forth the law, and the word of the Lord from Jerusalem"—some other law, that is, and another word.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 1:19
verses.text: In short, says he, "He shall judge among the nations, and shall rebuke many people;" meaning not those of the Jewish people only, but of the nations which are judged by the new law of the gospel and the new word of the apostles, and are amongst themselves rebuked of their old error as soon as they have believed.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 1:20
verses.text: And as the result of this, "they beat their swords into ploughshares, and their spears (which are a kind of hunting instruments) into pruning-hooks;" that is to say, minds, which once were fierce and cruel, are changed by them into good dispositions productive of good fruit.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 1:21
verses.text: And again:  "Hearken unto me, hearken unto me, my people, and ye kings, give ear unto me; for a law shall proceed from me, and my judgment for a light to the nations;" wherefore He had determined and decreed that the nations also were to be enlightened by the law and the word of the gospel.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 1:22
verses.text: This will be that law which (according to David also) is unblameable, because "perfect, converting the soul" from idols unto God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 1:23
verses.text: This likewise will be the word concerning which the same Isaiah says, "For the Lord will make a decisive word in the land".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 1:24
verses.text: Because the New Testament is compendiously short, and freed from the minute and perplexing burdens of the law.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 1:25
verses.text: But why enlarge, when the Creator by the same prophet foretells the renovation more manifestly and clearly than the light itself?  "Remember not the former things, neither consider the things of old" (the old things have passed away, and new things are arising).

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 1:26
verses.text: "Behold, I will do new things, which shall now spring forth".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 1:27
verses.text: So by Jeremiah: "Break up for yourselves new pastures, and sow not among thorns, and circumcise yourselves in the foreskin of your heart".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 1:28
verses.text: And in another passage: "Behold, the days come, saith the Lord, that I will make a new covenant with the house of Jacob, and with the house of Judah; not according to the covenant that I made with their fathers in the day when I arrested their dispensation, in order to bring them out of the land of Egypt".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 1:29
verses.text: He thus shows that the ancient covenant is temporary only, when He indicates its change; also when He promises that it shall be followed by an eternal one.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 1:30
verses.text: For by Isaiah He says: "Hear me, and ye shall live; and I will make an everlasting covenant with you," adding "the sure mercies of David," in order that He might show that that covenant was to run its course in Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 1:31
verses.text: That He was of the family of David, according to the genealogy of Mary, He declared in a figurative way even by the rod which was to proceed out of the stem of Jesse.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 1:32
verses.text: Forasmuch then as he said, that from the Creator there would come other laws, and other words, and new dispensations of covenants, indicating also that the very sacrifices were to receive higher offices, and that amongst all nations, by Malachi when he says: "I have no pleasure in you, saith the Lord, neither will I accept your sacrifices at your hands.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 1:33
verses.text: For from the rising of the sun, even unto the going down of the same, my name shall be great among the Gentiles; and in every place a sacrifice is offered unto my name, even a pure offering"—meaning simple prayer from a pure conscience,—it is of necessity that every change which comes as the result of innovation, introduces a diversity in those things of which the change is made, from which diversity arises also a contrariety.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 1:34
verses.text: For as there is nothing, after it has undergone a change, which does not become different, so there is nothing different which is not contrary.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 1:35
verses.text: Of that very thing, therefore, there will be predicated a contrariety in consequence of its diversity, to which there accrued a change of condition after an innovation.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 1:36
verses.text: He who brought about the change, the same instituted the diversity also; He who foretold the innovation, the same announced beforehand the contrariety likewise.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 1:37
verses.text: Why, in your interpretation, do you impute a difference in the state of things to a difference of powers? Why do you wrest to the Creator's prejudice those examples from which you draw your antitheses, when you may recognise them all in His sensations and affections? "I will wound," He says, "and I will heal;" "I will kill," He says again, "and I will make alive"—even the same "who createth evil and maketh peace;" from which you are used even to censure Him with the imputation of fickleness and inconstancy, as if He forbade what He commanded, and commanded what He forbade.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 1:38
verses.text: Why, then, have you not reckoned up the Antitheses also which occur in the natural works of the Creator, who is for ever contrary to Himself? You have not been able, unless I am misinformed, to recognise the fact, that the world, at all events, even amongst your people of Pontus, is made up of a diversity of elements which are hostile to one another.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 1:39
verses.text: It was therefore your bounden duty first to have determined that the god of the light was one being, and the god of darkness was another, in such wise that you might have been able to have distinctly asserted one of them to be the god of the law and the other the god of the gospel.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 1:40
verses.text: It is, however, the settled conviction already of my mind from manifest proofs, that, as His works and plans exist in the way of Antitheses, so also by the same rule exist the mysteries of His religion.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 2:1
verses.text: St.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 2:2
verses.text: Luke's Gospel, Selected by Marcion as His Authority, and Mutilated by Him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 2:3
verses.text: The Other Gospels Equally Authoritative.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 2:4
verses.text: Marcion's Terms of Discussion, However, Accepted, and Grappled with on the Footing of St.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 2:5
verses.text: Luke's Gospel Alone.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 2:6
verses.text: You have now our answer to the Antitheses compendiously indicated by us.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 2:7
verses.text: I pass on to give a proof of the Gospel—not, to be sure, of Jewry, but of Pontus—having become meanwhile adulterated; and this shall indicate the order by which we proceed.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 2:8
verses.text: We lay it down as our first position, that the evangelical Testament has apostles for its authors, to whom was assigned by the Lord Himself this office of publishing the gospel.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 2:9
verses.text: Since, however, there are apostolic men also, they are yet not alone, but appear with apostles and after apostles; because the preaching of disciples might be open to the suspicion of an affectation of glory, if there did not accompany it the authority of the masters, which means that of Christ, for it was that which made the apostles their masters.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 2:10
verses.text: Of the apostles, therefore, John and Matthew first instil faith into us; whilst of apostolic men, Luke and Mark renew it afterwards.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 2:11
verses.text: These all start with the same principles of the faith, so far as relates to the one only God the Creator and His Christ, how that He was born of the Virgin, and came to fulfil the law and the prophets.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 2:12
verses.text: Never mind if there does occur some variation in the order of their narratives, provided that there be agreement in the essential matter of the faith, in which there is disagreement with Marcion.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 2:13
verses.text: Marcion, on the other hand, you must know, ascribes no author to his Gospel, as if it could not be allowed him to affix a title to that from which it was no crime (in his eyes) to subvert the very body.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 2:14
verses.text: And here I might now make a stand, and contend that a work ought not to be recognised, which holds not its head erect, which exhibits no consistency, which gives no promise of credibility from the fulness of its title and the just profession of its author.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 2:15
verses.text: But we prefer to join issue on every point; nor shall we leave unnoticed what may fairly be understood to be on our side.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 2:16
verses.text: Now, of the authors whom we possess, Marcion seems to have singled out Luke for his mutilating process.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 2:17
verses.text: Luke, however, was not an apostle, but only an apostolic man; not a master, but a disciple, and so inferior to a master—at least as far subsequent to him as the apostle whom he followed (and that, no doubt, was Paul) was subsequent to the others; so that, had Marcion even published his Gospel in the name of St.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 2:18
verses.text: Paul himself, the single authority of the document, destitute of all support from preceding authorities, would not be a sufficient basis for our faith.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 2:19
verses.text: There would be still wanted that Gospel which St.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 2:20
verses.text: Paul found in existence, to which he yielded his belief, and with which he so earnestly wished his own to agree, that he actually on that account went up to Jerusalem to know and consult the apostles, "lest he should run, or had been running in vain;" in other words, that the faith which he had learned, and the gospel which he was preaching, might be in accordance with theirs.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 2:21
verses.text: Then, at last, having conferred with the (primitive) authors, and having agreed with them touching the rule of faith, they joined their hands in fellowship, and divided their labours thenceforth in the office of preaching the gospel, so that they were to go to the Jews, and St.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 2:22
verses.text: Paul to the Jews and the Gentiles.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 2:23
verses.text: Inasmuch, therefore, as the enlightener of St.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 2:24
verses.text: Luke himself desired the authority of his predecessors for both his own faith and preaching, how much more may not I require for Luke's Gospel that which was necessary for the Gospel of his master.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 3:1
verses.text: Marcion Insinuated the Untrustworthiness of Certain Apostles Whom St.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 3:2
verses.text: Paul Rebuked.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 3:3
verses.text: The Rebuke Shows that It Cannot Be Regarded as Derogating from Their Authority.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 3:4
verses.text: The Apostolic Gospels Perfectly Authentic.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 3:5
verses.text: In the scheme of Marcion, on the contrary, the mystery of the Christian religion begins from the discipleship of Luke.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 3:6
verses.text: Since, however, it was on its course previous to that point, it must have had its own authentic materials, by means of which it found its own way down to St.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 3:7
verses.text: Luke; and by the assistance of the testimony which it bore, Luke himself becomes admissible.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 3:8
verses.text: Well, but Marcion, finding the Epistle of Paul to the Galatians (wherein he rebukes even apostles) for "not walking uprightly according to the truth of the gospel," as well as accuses certain false apostles of perverting the gospel of Christ), labours very hard to destroy the character of those Gospels which are published as genuine and under the name of apostles, in order, forsooth, to secure for his own Gospel the credit which he takes away from them.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 3:9
verses.text: But then, even if he censures Peter and John and James, who were thought to be pillars, it is for a manifest reason.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 3:10
verses.text: They seemed to be changing their company from respect of persons.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 3:11
verses.text: And yet as Paul himself "became all things to all men," that he might gain all, it was possible that Peter also might have betaken himself to the same plan of practising somewhat different from what he taught.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 3:12
verses.text: And, in like manner, if false apostles also crept in, their character too showed itself in their insisting upon circumcision and the Jewish ceremonies.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 3:13
verses.text: So that it was not on account of their preaching, but of their conversation, that they were marked by St.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 3:14
verses.text: Paul, who would with equal impartiality have marked them with censure, if they had erred at all with respect to God the Creator or His Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 3:15
verses.text: Each several case will therefore have to be distinguished.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 3:16
verses.text: When Marcion complains that apostles are suspected (for their prevarication and dissimulation) of having even depraved the gospel, he thereby accuses Christ, by accusing those whom Christ chose.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 3:17
verses.text: If, then, the apostles, who are censured simply for inconsistency of walk, composed the Gospel in a pure form, but false apostles interpolated their true record; and if our own copies have been made from these, where will that genuine text of the apostle's writings be found which has not suffered adulteration? Which was it that enlightened Paul, and through him Luke? It is either completely blotted out, as if by some deluge—being obliterated by the inundation of falsifiers—in which case even Marcion does not possess the true Gospel; or else, is that very edition which Marcion alone possesses the true one, that is, of the apostles? How, then, does that agree with ours, which is said not to be (the work) of apostles, but of Luke? Or else, again, if that which Marcion uses is not to be attributed to Luke simply because it does agree with ours (which, of course, is, also adulterated in its title), then it is the work of apostles.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 3:18
verses.text: Our Gospel, therefore, which is in agreement with it, is equally the work of apostles, but also adulterated in its title.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 4:1
verses.text: Each Side Claims to Possess the True Gospel.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 4:2
verses.text: Antiquity the Criterion of Truth in Such a Matter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 4:3
verses.text: Marcion's Pretensions as an Amender of the Gospel.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 4:4
verses.text: We must follow, then, the clue of our discussion, meeting every effort of our opponents with reciprocal vigor.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 4:5
verses.text: I say that my Gospel is the true one; Marcion, that his is.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 4:6
verses.text: I affirm that Marcion's Gospel is adulterated; Marcion, that mine is.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 4:7
verses.text: Now what is to settle the point for us, except it be that principle of time, which rules that the authority lies with that which shall be found to be more ancient; and assumes as an elemental truth, that corruption (of doctrine) belongs to the side which shall be convicted of comparative lateness in its origin.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 4:8
verses.text: For, inasmuch as error is falsification of truth, it must needs be that truth therefore precede error.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 4:9
verses.text: A thing must exist prior to its suffering any casualty; and an object must precede all rivalry to itself.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 4:10
verses.text: Else how absurd it would be, that, when we have proved our position to be the older one, and Marcion's the later, ours should yet appear to be the false one, before it had even received from truth its objective existence; and Marcion's should also be supposed to have experienced rivalry at our hands, even before its publication; and, in fine, that that should be thought to be the truer position which is the later one—a century later than the publication of all the many and great facts and records of the Christian religion, which certainly could not have been published without, that is to say, before, the truth of the gospel.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 4:11
verses.text: With regard, then, to the pending question, of Luke's Gospel (so far as its being the common property of ourselves and Marcion enables it to be decisive of the truth,) that portion of it which we alone receive is so much older than Marcion, that Marcion himself once believed it, when in the first warmth of faith he contributed money to the Catholic church, which along with himself was afterwards rejected, when he fell away from our truth into his own heresy.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 4:12
verses.text: What if the Marcionites have denied that he held the primitive faith amongst ourselves, in the face even of his own letter? What, if they do not acknowledge the letter? They, at any rate, receive his Antitheses; and more than that, they make ostentatious use of them.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 4:13
verses.text: Proof out of these is enough for me.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 4:14
verses.text: For if the Gospel, said to be Luke's which is current amongst us (we shall see whether it be also current with Marcion), is the very one which, as Marcion argues in his Antitheses, was interpolated by the defenders of Judaism, for the purpose of such a conglomeration with it of the law and the prophets as should enable them out of it to fashion their Christ, surely he could not have so argued about it, unless he had found it (in such a form).

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 4:15
verses.text: No one censures things before they exist, when he knows not whether they will come to pass.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 4:16
verses.text: Emendation never precedes the fault.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 4:17
verses.text: To be sure, an amender of that Gospel, which had been all topsy-turvy from the days of Tiberius to those of Antoninus, first presented himself in Marcion alone—so long looked for by Christ, who was all along regretting that he had been in so great a hurry to send out his apostles without the support of Marcion! But for all that, heresy, which is for ever mending the Gospels, and corrupting them in the act, is an affair of man's audacity, not of God's authority; and if Marcion be even a disciple, he is yet not "above his master;" if Marcion be an apostle, still as Paul says, "Whether it be I or they, so we preach;" if Marcion be a prophet, even "the spirits of the prophets will be subject to the prophets," for they are not the authors of confusion, but of peace; or if Marcion be actually an angel, he must rather be designated "as anathema than as a preacher of the gospel," because it is a strange gospel which he has preached.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 4:18
verses.text: So that, whilst he amends, he only confirms both positions: both that our Gospel is the prior one, for he amends that which he has previously fallen in with; and that that is the later one, which, by putting it together out of the emendations of ours, he has made his own Gospel, and a novel one too.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 5:1
verses.text: By the Rule of Antiquity, the Catholic Gospels are Found to Be True, Including the Real St.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 5:2
verses.text: Luke's.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 5:3
verses.text: Marcion's Only a Mutilated Edition.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 5:4
verses.text: The Heretic's Weakness and Inconsistency in Ignoring the Other Gospels.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 5:5
verses.text: On the whole, then, if that is evidently more true which is earlier, if that is earlier which is from the very beginning, if that is from the beginning which has the apostles for its authors, then it will certainly be quite as evident, that that comes down from the apostles, which has been kept as a sacred deposit in the churches of the apostles.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 5:6
verses.text: Let us see what milk the Corinthians drank from Paul; to what rule of faith the Galatians were brought for correction; what the Philippians, the Thessalonians, the Ephesians read by it; what utterance also the Romans give, so very near (to the apostles), to whom Peter and Paul conjointly bequeathed the gospel even sealed with their own blood.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 5:7
verses.text: We have also St.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 5:8
verses.text: John's foster churches.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 5:9
verses.text: For although Marcion rejects his Apocalypse, the order of the bishops (thereof), when traced up to their origin, will yet rest on John as their author.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 5:10
verses.text: In the same manner is recognised the excellent source of the other churches.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 5:11
verses.text: I say, therefore, that in them (and not simply such of them as were founded by apostles, but in all those which are united with them in the fellowship of the mystery of the gospel of Christ) that Gospel of Luke which we are defending with all our might has stood its ground from its very first publication; whereas Marcion's Gospel is not known to most people, and to none whatever is it known without being at the same time condemned.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 5:12
verses.text: It too, of course, has its churches, but specially its own—as late as they are spurious; and should you want to know their original, you will more easily discover apostasy in it than apostolicity, with Marcion forsooth as their founder, or some one of Marcion's swarm.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 5:13
verses.text: Even wasps make combs; so also these Marcionites make churches.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 5:14
verses.text: The same authority of the apostolic churches will afford evidence to the other Gospels also, which we possess equally through their means, and according to their usage—I mean the Gospels of John and Matthew—whilst that which Mark published may be affirmed to be Peter's whose interpreter Mark was.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 5:15
verses.text: For even Luke's form of the Gospel men usually ascribe to Paul.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 5:16
verses.text: And it may well seem that the works which disciples publish belong to their masters.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 5:17
verses.text: Well, then, Marcion ought to be called to a strict account concerning these (other Gospels) also, for having omitted them, and insisted in preference on Luke; as if they, too, had not had free course in the churches, as well as Luke's Gospel, from the beginning.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 5:18
verses.text: Nay, it is even more credible that they existed from the very beginning; for, being the work of apostles, they were prior, and coeval in origin with the churches themselves.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 5:19
verses.text: But how comes it to pass, if the apostles published nothing, that their disciples were more forward in such a work; for they could not have been disciples, without any instruction from their masters? If, then, it be evident that these (Gospels) also were current in the churches, why did not Marcion touch them—either to amend them if they were adulterated, or to acknowledge them if they were uncorrupt?  For it is but natural that they who were perverting the gospel, should be more solicitous about the perversion of those things whose authority they knew to be more generally received.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 5:20
verses.text: Even the false apostles (were so called) on this very account, because they imitated the apostles by means of their falsification.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 5:21
verses.text: In as far, then, as he might have amended what there was to amend, if found corrupt, in so far did he firmly imply that all was free from corruption which he did not think required amendment.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 5:22
verses.text: In short, he simply amended what he thought was corrupt; though, indeed, not even this justly, because it was not really corrupt.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 5:23
verses.text: For if the (Gospels) of the apostles have come down to us in their integrity, whilst Luke's, which is received amongst us, so far accords with their rule as to be on a par with them in permanency of reception in the churches, it clearly follows that Luke's Gospel also has come down to us in like integrity until the sacrilegious treatment of Marcion.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 5:24
verses.text: In short, when Marcion laid hands on it, it then became diverse and hostile to the Gospels of the apostles.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 5:25
verses.text: I will therefore advise his followers, that they either change these Gospels, however late to do so, into a conformity with their own, whereby they may seem to be in agreement with the apostolic writings (for they are daily retouching their work, as daily they are convicted by us); or else that they blush for their master, who stands self-condemned either way—when once he hands on the truth of the gospel conscience smitten, or again subverts it by shameless tampering.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 5:26
verses.text: Such are the summary arguments which we use, when we take up arms against heretics for the faith of the gospel, maintaining both that order of periods, which rules that a late date is the mark of forgers, and that authority of churches which lends support to the tradition of the apostles; because truth must needs precede the forgery, and proceed straight from those by whom it has been handed on.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 6:1
verses.text: Marcion's Object in Adulterating the Gospel.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 6:2
verses.text: No Difference Between the Christ of the Creator and the Christ of the Gospel.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 6:3
verses.text: No Rival Christ Admissible.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 6:4
verses.text: The Connection of the True Christ with the Dispensation of the Old Testament Asserted.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 6:5
verses.text: But we now advance a step further on, and challenge (as we promised to do) the very Gospel of Marcion, with the intention of thus proving that it has been adulterated.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 6:6
verses.text: For it is certain that the whole aim at which he has strenuously laboured even in the drawing up of his Antitheses, centres in this, that he may establish a diversity between the Old and the New Testaments, so that his own Christ may be separate from the Creator, as belonging to this rival god, and as alien from the law and the prophets.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 6:7
verses.text: It is certain, also, that with this view he has erased everything that was contrary to his own opinion and made for the Creator, as if it had been interpolated by His advocates, whilst everything which agreed with his own opinion he has retained.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 6:8
verses.text: The latter statements we shall strictly examine; and if they shall turn out rather for our side, and shatter the assumption of Marcion, we shall embrace them.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 6:9
verses.text: It will then become evident, that in retaining them he has shown no less of the defect of blindness, which characterizes heresy, than he displayed when he erased all the former class of subjects.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 6:10
verses.text: Such, then, is to be the drift and form of my little treatise; subject, of course, to whatever condition may have become requisite on both sides of the question.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 6:11
verses.text: Marcion has laid down the position, that Christ who in the days of Tiberius was, by a previously unknown god, revealed for the salvation of all nations, is a different being from Him who was ordained by God the Creator for the restoration of the Jewish state, and who is yet to come.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 6:12
verses.text: Between these he interposes the separation of a great and absolute difference—as great as lies between what is just and what is good; as great as lies between the law and the gospel; as great, (in short,) as is the difference between Judaism and Christianity.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 6:13
verses.text: Hence will arise also our rule, by which we determine that there ought to be nothing in common between the Christ of the rival god and the Creator; but that (Christ) must be pronounced to belong to the Creator, if He has administered His dispensations, fulfilled His prophecies, promoted His laws, given reality to His promises, revived His mighty power, remoulded His determinations, expressed His attributes, His properties.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 6:14
verses.text: This law and this rule I earnestly request the reader to have ever in his mind, and so let him begin to investigate whether Christ be Marcion's or the Creator's.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 7:1
verses.text: Marcion Rejected the Preceding Portion of St.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 7:2
verses.text: Luke's Gospel.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 7:3
verses.text: Therefore This Review Opens with an Examination of the Case of the Evil Spirit in the Synagogue of Capernaum.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 7:4
verses.text: He Whom the Demon Acknowledged Was the Creator's Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 7:5
verses.text: In the fifteenth year of the reign of Tiberius (for such is Marcion's proposition) he "came down to the Galilean city of Capernaum," of course meaning from the heaven of the Creator, to which he had previously descended from his own.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 7:6
verses.text: What then had been his course, for him to be described as first descending from his own heaven to the Creator's? For why should I abstain from censuring those parts of the statement which do not satisfy the requirement of an ordinary narrative, but always end in a falsehood? To be sure, our censure has been once for all expressed in the question, which we have already suggested: Whether, when descending through the Creator's domain, and indeed in hostility to him, he could possibly have been admitted by him, and by him been transmitted to the earth, which was equally his territory? Now, however, I want also to know the remainder of his course down, assuming that he came down.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 7:7
verses.text: For we must not be too nice in inquiring whether it is supposed that he was seen in any place.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 7:8
verses.text: To come into view indicates a sudden unexpected glance, which for a moment fixed the eye upon the object that passed before the view, without staying.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 7:9
verses.text: But when it happens that a descent has been effected, it is apparent, and comes under the notice of the eyes.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 7:10
verses.text: Moreover, it takes account of fact, and thus obliges one to examine in what condition with what preparation, with how much violence or moderation, and further, at what time of the day or night, the descent was made; who, again, saw the descent, who reported it, who seriously avouched the fact, which certainly was not easy to be believed, even after the asseveration.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 7:11
verses.text: It is, in short, too bad that Romulus should have had in Proculus an avoucher of his ascent to heaven, when the Christ of (this) god could not find any one to announce his descent from heaven; just as if the ascent of the one and the descent of the other were not effected on one and the same ladder of falsehood! Then, what had he to do with Galilee, if he did not belong to the Creator by whom that region was destined (for His Christ) when about to enter on His ministry? As Isaiah says: "Drink in this first, and be prompt, O region of Zabulon and land of Nephthalim, and ye others who (inhabit) the sea-coast, and that of Jordan, Galilee of the nations, ye people who sit in darkness, behold a great light; upon you, who inhabit (that) land, sitting in the shadow of death, the light hath arisen".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 7:12
verses.text: It is, however, well that Marcion's god does claim to be the enlightener of the nations, that so he might have the better reason for coming down from heaven; only, if it must needs be, he should rather have made Pontus his place of descent than Galilee.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 7:13
verses.text: But since both the place and the work of illumination according to the prophecy are compatible with Christ, we begin to discern that He is the subject of the prophecy, which shows that at the very outset of His ministry, He came not to destroy the law and the prophets, but rather to fulfil them; for Marcion has erased the passage as an interpolation.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 7:14
verses.text: It will, however, be vain for him to deny that Christ uttered in word what He forthwith did partially indeed.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 7:15
verses.text: For the prophecy about place He at once fulfilled.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 7:16
verses.text: From heaven straight to the synagogue.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 7:17
verses.text: As the adage runs: "The business on which we are come, do at once".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 7:18
verses.text: Marcion must even expunge from the Gospel, "I am not sent but unto the lost sheep of the house of Israel;" and, "It is not meet to take the children's bread, and to cast it to dogs,"—in order, forsooth, that Christ may not appear to be an Israelite.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 7:19
verses.text: But facts will satisfy me instead of words.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 7:20
verses.text: Withdraw all the sayings of my Christ, His acts shall speak.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 7:21
verses.text: Lo, He enters the synagogue; surely (this is going) to the lost sheep of the house of Israel.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 7:22
verses.text: Behold, it is to Israelites first that He offers the "bread" of His doctrine; surely it is because they are "children" that He shows them this priority.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 7:23
verses.text: Observe, He does not yet impart it to others; surely He passes them by as "dogs".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 7:24
verses.text: For to whom else could He better have imparted it, than to such as were strangers to the Creator, if He especially belonged not to the Creator? And yet how could He have been admitted into the synagogue—one so abruptly appearing, so unknown; one, of whom no one had as yet been apprised of His tribe, His nation, His family, and lastly, His enrolment in the census of Augustus—that most faithful witness of the Lord's nativity, kept in the archives of Rome? They certainly would have remembered, if they did not know Him to be circumcised, that He must not be admitted into their most holy places.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 7:25
verses.text: And even if He had the general right of entering the synagogue (like other Jews), yet the function of giving instruction was allowed only to a man who was extremely well known, and examined and tried, and for some time invested with the privilege after experience duly attested elsewhere.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 7:26
verses.text: But "they were all astonished at His doctrine".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 7:27
verses.text: Of course they were; "for, says (St.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 7:28
verses.text: Luke), "His word was with power—not because He taught in opposition to the law and the prophets.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 7:29
verses.text: No doubt, His divine discourse gave forth both power and grace, building up rather than pulling down the substance of the law and the prophets.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 7:30
verses.text: Otherwise, instead of "astonishment, they would feel horror.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 7:31
verses.text: It would not be admiration, but aversion, prompt and sure, which they would bestow on one who was the destroyer of law and prophets, and the especial propounder as a natural consequence of a rival god; for he would have been unable to teach anything to the disparagement of the law and the prophets, and so far of the Creator also, without premising the doctrine of a different and rival divinity.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 7:32
verses.text: Inasmuch, then, as the Scripture makes no other statement on the matter than that the simple force and power of His word produced astonishment, it more naturally shows that His teaching was in accordance with the Creator by not denying (that it was so), than that it was in opposition to the Creator, by not asserting (such a fact).

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 7:33
verses.text: And thus He will either have to be acknowledged as belonging to Him, in accordance with whom He taught; or else will have to be adjudged a deceiver since He taught in accordance with One whom He had come to oppose.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 7:34
verses.text: In the same passage, "the spirit of an unclean devil" exclaims: "What have we to do with Thee, Thou Jesus? Art Thou come to destroy us? I know Thee who Thou art, the Holy One of God".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 7:35
verses.text: I do not here raise the question whether this appellation was suitable to one who ought not to be called Christ, unless he were sent by the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 7:36
verses.text: Elsewhere there has been already given a full consideration of His titles.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 7:37
verses.text: My present discussion is, how the evil spirit could have known that He was called by such a name, when there had never at any time been uttered about Him a single prophecy by a god who was unknown, and up to that time silent, of whom it was not possible for Him to be attested as "the Holy One," as (of a god) unknown even to his own Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 7:38
verses.text: What similar event could he then have published of a new deity, whereby he might betoken for "the holy one" of the rival god?  Simply that he went into the synagogue, and did nothing even in word against the Creator? As therefore he could not by any means acknowledge him, whom he was ignorant of, to be Jesus and the Holy One of God; so did he acknowledge Him whom he knew (to be both).

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 7:39
verses.text: For he remembered how that the prophet had prophesied of "the Holy One" of God, and how that God's name of "Jesus" was in the son of Nun.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 7:40
verses.text: These facts he had also received from the angel, according to our Gospel:  "Wherefore that which shall be born of thee shall be called the Holy One, the Son of God;" and, "Thou shalt call his name Jesus".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 7:41
verses.text: Thus he actually had (although only an evil spirit) some idea of the Lord's dispensation, rather than of any strange and heretofore imperfectly understood one.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 7:42
verses.text: Because he also premised this question:  "What have we to do with Thee?"—not as if referring to a strange Jesus, to whom pertain the evil spirits of the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 7:43
verses.text: Nor did he say, What hast Thou to do with us? but, "What have we to do with Thee?" as if deploring himself, and deprecating his own calamity; at the prospect of which he adds: "Art Thou come to destroy us?" So completely did he acknowledge in Jesus the Son of that God who was judicial and avenging, and (so to speak) severe, and not of him who was simply good, and knew not how to destroy or how to punish!  Now for what purpose have we adduced his passage first? In order to show that Jesus was neither acknowledged by the evil spirit, nor affirmed by Himself, to be any other than the Creator's.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 7:44
verses.text: Well, but Jesus rebuked him, you say.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 7:45
verses.text: To be sure he did, as being an envious (spirit), and in his very confession only petulant, and evil in adulation—just as if it had been Christ's highest glory to have come for the destruction of demons, and not for the salvation of mankind; whereas His wish really was that His disciples should not glory in the subjection of evil spirits but in the fair beauty of salvation.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 7:46
verses.text: Why else did He rebuke him? If it was because he was entirely wrong (in his invocation), then He was neither Jesus nor the Holy One of God; if it was because he was partially wrong—for having supposed him to be, rightly enough, Jesus and the Holy One of God, but also as belonging to the Creator—most unjustly would He have rebuked him for thinking what he knew he ought to think (about Him), and for not supposing that of Him which he knew not that he ought to suppose—that he was another Jesus, and the holy one of the other god.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 7:47
verses.text: If, however, the rebuke has not a more probable meaning than that which we ascribe to it, it follows that the evil spirit made no mistake, and was not rebuked for lying; for it was Jesus Himself, besides whom it was impossible for the evil spirit to have acknowledged any other, whilst Jesus affirmed that He was He whom the evil spirit had acknowledged, by not rebuking him for uttering a lie.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 8:1
verses.text: Other Proofs from the Same Chapter, that Jesus, Who Preached at Nazareth, and Was Acknowledged by Certain Demons as Christ the Son of God, Was the Creator's Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 8:2
verses.text: As Occasion Offers, the Docetic Errors of Marcion are Exposed.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 8:3
verses.text: The Christ of the Creator had to be called a Nazarene according to prophecy; whence the Jews also designate us, on that very account, Nazerenes after Him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 8:4
verses.text: For we are they of whom it is written, "Her Nazarites were whiter than snow;" even they who were once defiled with the stains of sin, and darkened with the clouds of ignorance.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 8:5
verses.text: But to Christ the title Nazarene was destined to become a suitable one, from the hiding-place of His infancy, for which He went down and dwelt at Nazareth, to escape from Archelaus the son of Herod.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 8:6
verses.text: This fact I have not refrained from mentioning on this account, because it behoved Marcion's Christ to have forborne all connection whatever with the domestic localities of the Creator's Christ, when he had so many towns in Judaea which had not been by the prophets thus assigned to the Creator's Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 8:7
verses.text: But Christ will be (the Christ) of the prophets, wheresoever He is found in accordance with the prophets.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 8:8
verses.text: And yet even at Nazareth He is not remarked as having preached anything new, whilst in another verse He is said to have been rejected by reason of a simple proverb.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 8:9
verses.text: Here at once, when I observe that they laid their hands on Him, I cannot help drawing a conclusion respecting His bodily substance, which cannot be believed to have been a phantom, since it was capable of being touched and even violently handled, when He was seized and taken and led to the very brink of a precipice.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 8:10
verses.text: For although He escaped through the midst of them, He had already experienced their rough treatment, and afterwards went His way, no doubt because the crowd (as usually happens) gave way, or was even broken through; but not because it was eluded as by an impalpable disguise, which, if there had been such, would not at all have submitted to any touch.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 8:11
verses.text: "Tangere enim et tangi, nisi corpus, nulla potest res,"  is even a sentence worthy of a place in the world's wisdom.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 8:12
verses.text: In short, He did himself touch others, upon whom He laid His hands, which were capable of being felt, and conferred the blessings of healing, which were not less true, not less unimaginary, than were the hands wherewith He bestowed them.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 8:13
verses.text: He was therefore the very Christ of Isaiah, the healer of our sicknesses.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 8:14
verses.text: "Surely," says he, "He hath borne our griefs and carried our sorrows".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 8:15
verses.text: Now the Greeks are accustomed to use for carry a word which also signifies to take away.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 8:16
verses.text: A general promise is enough for me in passing.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 8:17
verses.text: Whatever were the cures which Jesus effected, He is mine.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 8:18
verses.text: We will come, however, to the kinds of cures.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 8:19
verses.text: To liberate men, then, from evil spirits, is a cure of sickness.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 8:20
verses.text: Accordingly, wicked spirits (just in the manner of our former example) used to go forth with a testimony, exclaiming, "Thou art the Son of God,"—of what God, is clear enough from the case itself.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 8:21
verses.text: But they were rebuked, and ordered not to speak; precisely because Christ willed Himself to be proclaimed by men, not by unclean spirits, as the Son of God—even that Christ alone to whom this was befitting, because He had sent beforehand men through whom He might become known, and who were assuredly worthier preachers.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 8:22
verses.text: It was natural to Him to refuse the proclamation of an unclean spirit, at whose command there was an abundance of saints.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 8:23
verses.text: He, however, who had never been foretold (if, indeed, he wished to be acknowledged; for if he did not wish so much, his coming was in vain), would not have spurned the testimony of an alien or any sort of substance, who did not happen to have a substance of his own, but had descended in an alien one.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 8:24
verses.text: And now, too, as the destroyer also of the Creator, he would have desired nothing better than to be acknowledged by His spirits, and to be divulged for the sake of being feared: only that Marcion says that his god is not feared; maintaining that a good being is not an object of fear, but only a judicial being, in whom reside the grounds of fear—anger, severity, judgments, vengeance, condemnation.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 8:25
verses.text: But it was from fear, undoubtedly, that the evil spirits were cowed.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 8:26
verses.text: Therefore they confessed that (Christ) was the Son of a God who was to be feared, because they would have an occasion of not submitting if there were none for fearing.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 8:27
verses.text: Besides, He showed that He was to be feared, because He drave them out, not by persuasion like a good being, but by command and reproof.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 8:28
verses.text: Or else did he reprove them, because they were making him an object of fear, when all the while he did not want to be feared? And in what manner did he wish them to go forth, when they could not do so except with fear? So that he fell into the dilemma of having to conduct himself contrary to his nature, whereas he might in his simple goodness have at once treated them with leniency.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 8:29
verses.text: He fell, too, into another false position—of prevarication, when he permitted himself to be feared by the demons as the Son of the Creator, that he might drive them out, not indeed by his own power, but by the authority of the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 8:30
verses.text: "He departed, and went into a desert place".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 8:31
verses.text: This was, indeed, the Creator's customary region.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 8:32
verses.text: It was proper that the Word should there appear in body, where He had aforetime, wrought in a cloud.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 8:33
verses.text: To the gospel also was suitable that condition of place which had once been determined on for the law.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 8:34
verses.text: "Let the wilderness and the solitary place, therefore, be glad and rejoice;" so had Isaiah promised.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 8:35
verses.text: When "stayed" by the crowds, He said, "I must preach the kingdom of God to other cities also".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 8:36
verses.text: Had He displayed His God anywhere yet? I suppose as yet nowhere.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 8:37
verses.text: But was He speaking of those who knew of another god also? I do not believe so.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 8:38
verses.text: If, therefore, neither He had preached, nor they had known, any other God but the Creator, He was announcing the kingdom of that God whom He knew to be the only God known to those who were listening to Him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 9:1
verses.text: Out of St.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 9:2
verses.text: Luke's Fifth Chapter are Found Proofs of Christ's Belonging to the Creator, E.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 9:3
verses.text: g.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 9:4
verses.text: In the Call of Fishermen to the Apostolic Office, and in the Cleansing of the Leper.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 9:5
verses.text: Christ Compared with the Prophet Elisha.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 9:6
verses.text: Out of so many kinds of occupations, why indeed had He such respect for that of fishermen, as to select from it for apostles Simon and the sons of Zebedee (for it cannot seem to be the mere fact itself for which the narrative was meant to be drawn out), saying to Peter, when he trembled at the very large draught of the fishes, "Fear not; from henceforth thou shalt catch men?" By saying this, He suggested to them the meaning of the fulfilled prophecy, that it was even He who by Jeremiah had foretold, "Behold, I will send many fishers; and they shall fish them," that is, men.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 9:7
verses.text: Then at last they left their boats, and followed Him, understanding that it was He who had begun to accomplish what He had declared.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 9:8
verses.text: It is quite another case, when he affected to choose from the college of shipmasters, intending one day to appoint the shipmaster Marcion his apostle.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 9:9
verses.text: We have indeed already laid it down, in opposition to his Antitheses, that the position of Marcion derives no advantage from the diversity which he supposes to exist between the Law and the Gospel, inasmuch as even this was ordained by the Creator, and indeed predicted in the promise of the new Law, and the new Word, and the new Testament.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 9:10
verses.text: Since, however, he quotes with especial care, as a proof in his domain, a certain companion in misery (συνταλαίπωρον), and associate in hatred (συμμισούμενον ), with himself, for the cure of leprosy, I shall not be sorry to meet him, and before anything else to point out to him the force of the law figuratively interpreted, which, in this example of a leper (who was not to be touched, but was rather to be removed from all intercourse with others), prohibited any communication with a person who was defiled with sins, with whom the apostle also forbids us even to eat food, forasmuch as the taint of sins would be communicated as if contagious, wherever a man should mix himself with the sinner.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 9:11
verses.text: The Lord, therefore, wishing that the law should be more profoundly understood as signifying spiritual truths by carnal facts—and thus not destroying, but rather building up, that law which He wanted to have more earnestly acknowledged—touched the leper, by whom (even although as man He might have been defiled) He could not be defiled as God, being of course incorruptible.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 9:12
verses.text: The prescription, therefore, could not be meant for Him, that He was bound to observe the law and not touch the unclean person, seeing that contact with the unclean would not cause defilement to Him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 9:13
verses.text: I thus teach that this (immunity) is consistent in my Christ, the rather when I show that it is not consistent in yours.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 9:14
verses.text: Now, if it was as an enemy of the law that He touched the leper—disregarding the precept of the law by a contempt of the defilement—how could he be defiled, when he possessed not a body which could be defiled? For a phantom is not susceptible of defilement.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 9:15
verses.text: He therefore, who could not be defiled, as being a phantom, will not have an immunity from pollution by any divine power, but owing to his fantastic vacuity; nor can he be regarded as having despised pollution, who had not in fact any material capacity for it; nor, in like manner, as having destroyed the law, who had escaped defilement from the occasion of his phantom nature, not from any display of virtue.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 9:16
verses.text: If, however, the Creator's prophet Elisha cleansed Naaman the Syrian alone, to the exclusion of so many lepers in Israel, this fact contributes nothing to the distinction of Christ, as if he were in this way the better one for cleansing this Israelite leper, although a stranger to him, whom his own Lord had been unable to cleanse.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 9:17
verses.text: The cleansing of the Syrian rather was significant throughout the nations of the world of their own cleansing in Christ their light, steeped as they were in the stains of the seven deadly sins: idolatry, blasphemy, murder, adultery, fornication, false-witness, and fraud.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 9:18
verses.text: Seven times, therefore, as if once for each, did he wash in Jordan; both in order that he might celebrate the expiation of a perfect hebdomad; and because the virtue and fulness of the one baptism was thus solemnly imputed to Christ, alone, who was one day to establish on earth not only a revelation, but also a baptism, endued with compendious efficacy.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 9:19
verses.text: Even Marcion finds here an antithesis: how that Elisha indeed required a material resource, applied water, and that seven times; whereas Christ, by the employment of a word only, and that but once for all, instantly effected the cure.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 9:20
verses.text: And surely I might venture to claim the Very Word also as of the Creator's substance.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 9:21
verses.text: There is nothing of which He who was the primitive Author is not also the more powerful one.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 9:22
verses.text: Forsooth, it is incredible that that power of the Creator should have, by a word, produced a remedy for a single malady, which once by a word brought into being so vast a fabric as the world! From what can the Christ of the Creator be better discerned, than from the power of His word? But Christ is on this account another (Christ), because He acted differently from Elisha—because, in fact, the master is more powerful than his servant! Why, Marcion, do you lay down the rule, that things are done by servants just as they are by their very masters? Are you not afraid that it will turn to your discredit, if you deny that Christ belongs to the Creator, on the ground that He was once more powerful than a servant of the Creator—since, in comparison with the weakness of Elisha, He is acknowledged to be the greater, if indeed greater! For the cure is the same, although there is a difference in the working of it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 9:23
verses.text: What has your Christ performed more than my Elisha?  Nay, what great thing has the word of your Christ performed, when it has simply done that which a river of the Creator effected? On the same principle occurs all the rest.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 9:24
verses.text: So far as renouncing all human glory went, He forbade the man to publish abroad the cure; but so far as the honour of the law was concerned, He requested that the usual course should be followed: "Go, show thyself to the priest, and present the offering which Moses commanded".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 9:25
verses.text: For the figurative signs of the law in its types He still would have observed, because of their prophetic import.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 9:26
verses.text: These types signified that a man, once a sinner, but afterwards purified from the stains thereof by the word of God, was bound to offer unto God in the temple a gift, even prayer and thanksgiving in the church through Christ Jesus, who is the Catholic Priest of the Father.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 9:27
verses.text: Accordingly He added: "that it may be for a testimony unto you"—one, no doubt, whereby He would testify that He was not destroying the law, but fulfilling it; whereby, too, He would testify that it was He Himself who was foretold as about to undertake their sicknesses and infirmities.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 9:28
verses.text: This very consistent and becoming explanation of "the testimony," that adulator of his own Christ, Marcion seeks to exclude under the cover of mercy and gentleness.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 9:29
verses.text: For, being both good (such are his words), and knowing, besides, that every man who had been freed from leprosy would be sure to perform the solemnities of the law, therefore He gave this precept.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 9:30
verses.text: Well, what then? Has He continued in his goodness (that is to say, in his permission of the law) or not?  For if he has persevered in his goodness, he will never become a destroyer of the law; nor will he ever be accounted as belonging to another god, because there would not exist that destruction of the law which would constitute his claim to belong to the other god.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 9:31
verses.text: If, however, he has not continued good, by a subsequent destruction of the law, it is a false testimony which he has since imposed upon them in his cure of the leper; because he has forsaken his goodness, in destroying the law.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 9:32
verses.text: If, therefore, he was good whilst upholding the law, he has now become evil as a destroyer of the law.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 9:33
verses.text: However, by the support which he gave to the law, he affirmed that the law was good.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 9:34
verses.text: For no one permits himself in the support of an evil thing.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 9:35
verses.text: Therefore he is not only bad if he has permitted obedience to a bad law; but even worse still, if he has appeared as the destroyer of a good law.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 9:36
verses.text: So that if he commanded the offering of the gift because he knew that every cured leper would be sure to bring one; he possibly abstained from commanding what he knew would be spontaneously done.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 9:37
verses.text: In vain, therefore, was his coming down, as if with the intention of destroying the law, when he makes concessions to the keepers of the law.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 9:38
verses.text: And yet, because he knew their disposition, he ought the more earnestly to have prevented their neglect of the law, since he had come for this purpose.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 9:39
verses.text: Why then did he not keep silent, that man might of his own simple will obey the law? For then might he have seemed to some extent to have persisted in his patience.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 9:40
verses.text: But he adds also his own authority increased by the weight of this "testimony".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 9:41
verses.text: Of what testimony, I ask, if not that of the assertion of the law?  Surely it matters not in what way he asserted the law—whether as good, or as supererogatory, or as patient, or as inconstant—provided, Marcion, I drive you from your position.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 9:42
verses.text: Observe, he commanded that the law should be fulfilled.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 9:43
verses.text: In whatever way he commanded it, in the same way might he also have first uttered that sentiment: "I came not to destroy the law, but to fulfil it".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 9:44
verses.text: What business, therefore, had you to erase out of the Gospel that which was quite consistent in it? For you have confessed that, in his goodness, he did in act what you deny that he did in word.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 9:45
verses.text: We have therefore good proof that He uttered the word, in the fact that He did the deed; and that you have rather expunged the Lord's word, than that our (evangelists) have inserted it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 10:1
verses.text: Further Proofs of the Same Truth in the Same Chapter, from the Healing of the Paralytic, and from the Designation Son of Man Which Jesus Gives Himself.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 10:2
verses.text: Tertullian Sustains His Argument by Several Quotations from the Prophets.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 10:3
verses.text: The sick of the palsy is healed, and that in public, in the sight of the people.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 10:4
verses.text: For, says Isaiah, "they shall see the glory of the Lord, and the excellency of our God".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 10:5
verses.text: What glory, and what excellency? "Be strong, ye weak hands, and ye feeble knees:" this refers to the palsy.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 10:6
verses.text: "Be strong; fear not".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 10:7
verses.text: Be strong is not vainly repeated, nor is fear not vainly added; because with the renewal of the limbs there was to be, according to the promise, a restoration also of bodily energies: "Arise, and take up thy couch;" and likewise moral courage not to be afraid of those who should say, "Who can forgive sins, but God alone?" So that you have here not only the fulfilment of the prophecy which promised a particular kind of healing, but also of the symptoms which followed the cure.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 10:8
verses.text: In like manner, you should also recognise Christ in the same prophet as the forgiver of sins.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 10:9
verses.text: "For," he says, "He shall remit to many their sins, and shall Himself take away our sins".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 10:10
verses.text: For in an earlier passage, speaking in the person of the Lord himself, he had said:  "Even though your sins be as scarlet, I will make them as white as snow; even though they be like crimson, I will whiten them as wool".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 10:11
verses.text: In the scarlet colour He indicates the blood of the prophets; in the crimson, that of the Lord, as the brighter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 10:12
verses.text: Concerning the forgiveness of sins, Micah also says: "Who is a God like unto Thee? pardoning iniquity, and passing by the transgressions of the remnant of Thine heritage.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 10:13
verses.text: He retaineth not His anger as a testimony against them, because He delighteth in mercy.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 10:14
verses.text: He will turn again, and will have compassion upon us; He wipeth away our iniquities, and casteth our sins into the depths of the sea".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 10:15
verses.text: Now, if nothing of this sort had been predicted of Christ, I should find in the Creator examples of such a benignity as would hold out to me the promise of similar affections also in the Son of whom He is the Father.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 10:16
verses.text: I see how the Ninevites obtained forgiveness of their sins from the Creator—not to say from Christ, even then, because from the beginning He acted in the Father's name.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 10:17
verses.text: I read, too, how that, when David acknowledged his sin against Uriah, the prophet Nathan said unto him, "The Lord hath cancelled thy sin, and thou shalt not die;" how king Ahab in like manner, the husband of Jezebel, guilty of idolatry and of the blood of Naboth, obtained pardon because of his repentance; and how Jonathan the son of Saul blotted out by his deprecation the guilt of a violated fast.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 10:18
verses.text: Why should I recount the frequent restoration of the nation itself after the forgiveness of their sins?—by that God, indeed, who will have mercy rather than sacrifice, and a sinner's repentance rather than his death.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 10:19
verses.text: You will first have to deny that the Creator ever forgave sins; then you must in reason show that He never ordained any such prerogative for His Christ; and so you will prove how novel is that boasted benevolence of the, of course, novel Christ when you shall have proved that it is neither compatible with the Creator nor predicted by the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 10:20
verses.text: But whether to remit sins can appertain to one who is said to be unable to retain them, and whether to absolve can belong to him who is incompetent even to condemn, and whether to forgive is suitable to him against whom no offence can be committed, are questions which we have encountered elsewhere, when we preferred to drop suggestions rather than treat them anew.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 10:21
verses.text: Concerning the Son of man our rule is a twofold one: that Christ cannot lie, so as to declare Himself the Son of man, if He be not truly so; nor can He be constituted the Son of man, unless He be born of a human parent, either father or mother.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 10:22
verses.text: And then the discussion will turn on the point, of which human parent He ought to be accounted the son—of the father or the mother?  Since He is (begotten) of God the Father, He is not, of course, (the son) of a human father.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 10:23
verses.text: If He is not of a human father, it follows that He must be (the son) of a human mother.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 10:24
verses.text: If of a human mother, it is evident that she must be a virgin.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 10:25
verses.text: For to whom a human father is not ascribed, to his mother a husband will not be reckoned; and then to what mother a husband is not reckoned, the condition of virginity belongs.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 10:26
verses.text: But if His mother be not a virgin, two fathers will have to be reckoned to Him—a divine and a human one.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 10:27
verses.text: For she must have a husband, not to be a virgin; and by having a husband, she would cause two fathers—one divine, the other human—to accrue to Him, who would thus be Son both of God and of a man.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 10:28
verses.text: Such a nativity (if one may call it so) the mythic stories assign to Castor or to Hercules.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 10:29
verses.text: Now, if this distinction be observed, that is to say, if He be Son of man as born of His mother, because not begotten of a father, and His mother be a virgin, because His father is not human—He will be that Christ whom Isaiah foretold that a virgin should conceive, on what principle you, Marcion, can admit Him Son of man, I cannot possibly see.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 10:30
verses.text: If through a human father, then you deny him to be Son of God; if through a divine one also, then you make Christ the Hercules of fable; if through a human mother only, then you concede my point; if not through a human father also, then He is not the son of any man, and He must have been guilty of a lie for having declared Himself to be what He was not.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 10:31
verses.text: One thing alone can help you in your difficulty: boldness on your part either to surname your God as actually the human father of Christ, as Valentinus did with his aeon; or else to deny that the Virgin was human, which even Valentinus did not do.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 10:32
verses.text: What now, if Christ be described in Daniel by this very title of "Son of man?"  Is not this enough to prove that He is the Christ of prophecy? For if He gives Himself that appellation which was provided in the prophecy for the Christ of the Creator, He undoubtedly offers Himself to be understood as Him to whom (the appellation) was assigned by the prophet.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 10:33
verses.text: But perhaps it can be regarded as a simple identity of names; and yet we have maintained that neither Christ nor Jesus ought to have been called by these names, if they possessed any condition of diversity.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 10:34
verses.text: But as regards the appellation "Son of man," in as far as it occurs by accident, in so far there is a difficulty in its occurrence along with a casual identity of names.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 10:35
