verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 17:5
verses.text: Christ's Teaching Throughout Proves Him to Be Sent by the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 17:6
verses.text: And now, on the subject of a loan, when He asks, "And if ye lend to them of whom ye hope to receive, what thank have ye?" compare with this the following words of Ezekiel, in which He says of the before-mentioned just man, "He hath not given his money upon usury, nor will he take any increase"—meaning the redundance of interest, which is usury.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 17:7
verses.text: The first step was to eradicate the fruit of the money lent, the more easily to accustom a man to the loss, should it happen, of the money itself, the interest of which he had learnt to lose.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 17:8
verses.text: Now this, we affirm, was the function of the law as preparatory to the gospel.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 17:9
verses.text: It was engaged in forming the faith of such as would learn, by gradual stages, for the perfect light of the Christian discipline, through the best precepts of which it was capable, inculcating a benevolence which as yet expressed itself but falteringly.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 17:10
verses.text: For in the passage of Ezekiel quoted above He says, "And thou shalt restore the pledge of the loan"—to him, certainly, who is incapable of repayment, because, as a matter of course, He would not anyhow prescribe the restoration of a pledge to one who was solvent.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 17:11
verses.text: Much more clearly is it enjoined in Deuteronomy: "Thou shalt not sleep upon his pledge; thou shalt be sure to return to him his garment about sunset, and he shall sleep in his own garment".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 17:12
verses.text: Clearer still is a former passage: "Thou shalt remit every debt which thy neighbour oweth thee; and of thy brother thou shalt not require it, because it is called the release of the Lord thy God".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 17:13
verses.text: Now, when He commands that a debt be remitted to a man who shall be unable to pay it (for it is a still stronger argument when He forbids its being asked for from a man who is even able to repay it), what else does He teach than that we should lend to those of whom we cannot receive again, inasmuch as He has imposed so great a loss on lending? "And ye shall be the children of God".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 17:14
verses.text: What can be more shameless, than for him to be making us his children, who has not permitted us to make children for ourselves by forbidding marriage? How does he propose to invest his followers with a name which he has already erased?  I cannot be the son of a eunuch especially when I have for my Father the same great Being whom the universe claims for its! For is not the Founder of the universe as much a Father, even of all men, as (Marcion's) castrated deity, who is the maker of no existing thing?  Even if the Creator had not united male and female, and if He had not allowed any living creature whatever to have children, I yet had this relation to Him before Paradise, before the fall, before the expulsion, before the two became one.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 17:15
verses.text: I became His son a second time, as soon as He fashioned me with His hands, and gave me motion with His inbreathing.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 17:16
verses.text: Now again He names me His son, not begetting me into natural life, but into spiritual life.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 17:17
verses.text: "Because," says He, "He is kind unto the unthankful and to the evil".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 17:18
verses.text: Well done, Marcion! how cleverly have you withdrawn from Him the showers and the sunshine, that He might not seem to be a Creator!  But who is this kind being which hitherto has not been even known?  How can he be kind who had previously shown no evidences of such a kindness as this, which consists of the loan to us of sunshine and rain?—who is not destined to receive from the human race (the homage due to that) Creator,—who, up to this very moment, in return for His vast liberality in the gift of the elements, bears with men while they offer to idols, more readily than Himself, the due returns of His graciousness.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 17:19
verses.text: But God is truly kind even in spiritual blessings.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 17:20
verses.text: "The utterances of the Lord are sweeter than honey and honeycombs".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 17:21
verses.text: He then has taunted men as ungrateful who deserved to have their gratitude—even He, whose sunshine and rain even you, O Marcion, have enjoyed, but without gratitude! Your god, however, had no right to complain of man's ingratitude, because he had used no means to make them grateful.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 17:22
verses.text: Compassion also does He teach: "Be ye merciful," says He, "as your Father also that had mercy upon you".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 17:23
verses.text: This injunction will be of a piece with, "Deal thy bread to the hungry; and if he be houseless, bring him into thine house; and if thou seest the naked, cover him;" also with, "Judge the fatherless, plead with the widow".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 17:24
verses.text: I recognise here that ancient doctrine of Him who "prefers mercy to sacrifice".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 17:25
verses.text: If, however, it be now some other being which teaches mercy, on the ground of his own mercifulness, how happens it that he has been wanting in mercy to me for so vast an age? "Judge not, and ye shall not be judged; condemn not, and ye shall not be condemned; forgive, and ye shall be forgiven; give, and it shall be given unto you:  good measure, pressed down, and running over, shall men give into your bosom.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 17:26
verses.text: For with the same measure that ye measure withal, it shall be measured to you again".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 17:27
verses.text: As it seems to me, this passage announces a retribution proportioned to the merits.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 17:28
verses.text: But from whom shall come the retribution? If only from men, in that case he teaches a merely human discipline and recompense; and in everything we shall have to obey man: if from the Creator, as the Judge and the Recompenser of merits, then He compels our submission to Him, in whose hands He has placed a retribution which will be acceptable or terrible according as every man shall have judged or condemned, acquitted or dealt with, his neighbour; if from (Marcion's god) himself, he will then exercise a judicial function which Marcion denies.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 17:29
verses.text: Let the Marcionites therefore make their choice: Will it not be just the same inconsistency to desert the prescription of their master, as to have Christ teaching in the interest of men or of the Creator? But "a blind man will lead a blind man into the ditch".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 17:30
verses.text: Some persons believe Marcion.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 17:31
verses.text: But "the disciple is not above his master".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 17:32
verses.text: Apelles ought to have remembered this—a corrector of Marcion, although his disciple.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 17:33
verses.text: The heretic ought to take the beam out of his own eye, and then he may convict the Christian, should he suspect a mote to be in his eye.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 17:34
verses.text: Just as a good tree cannot produce evil fruit, so neither can truth generate heresy; and as a corrupt tree cannot yield good fruit, so heresy will not produce truth.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 17:35
verses.text: Thus, Marcion brought nothing good out of Cerdon's evil treasure; nor Apelles out of Marcion's.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 17:36
verses.text: For in applying to these heretics the figurative words which Christ used of men in general, we shall make a much more suitable interpretation of them than if we were to deduce out of them two gods, according to Marcion's grievous exposition.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 17:37
verses.text: I think that I have the best reason possible for insisting still upon the position which I have all along occupied, that in no passage to be anywhere found has another God been revealed by Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 17:38
verses.text: I wonder that in this place alone Marcion's hands should have felt benumbed in their adulterating labour.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 17:39
verses.text: But even robbers have their qualms now and then.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 17:40
verses.text: There is no wrong-doing without fear, because there is none without a guilty conscience.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 17:41
verses.text: So long, then, were the Jews cognisant of no other god but Him, beside whom they knew none else; nor did they call upon any other than Him whom alone they knew.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 17:42
verses.text: This being the case, who will He clearly be that said, "Why callest thou me Lord, Lord?" Will it be he who had as yet never been called on, because never yet revealed; or He who was ever regarded as the Lord, because known from the beginning—even the God of the Jews? Who, again, could possibly have added, "and do not the things which I say?" Could it have been he who was only then doing his best to teach them? Or He who from the beginning had addressed to them His messages both by the law and the prophets? He could then upbraid them with disobedience, even if He had no ground at any time else for His reproof.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 17:43
verses.text: The fact is, that He who was then imputing to them their ancient obstinacy was none other than He who, before the coming of Christ, had addressed to them these words, "This people honoureth me with their lips, but their heart standeth far off from me".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 17:44
verses.text: Otherwise, how absurd it were that a new god, a new Christ, the revealer of a new and so grand a religion should denounce as obstinate and disobedient those whom he had never had it in his power to make trial of!.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 18:1
verses.text: Concerning the Centurion's Faith.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 18:2
verses.text: The Raising of the Widow's Son.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 18:3
verses.text: John Baptist, and His Message to Christ; And the Woman Who Was a Sinner.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 18:4
verses.text: Proofs Extracted from All of the Relation of Christ to the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 18:5
verses.text: Likewise, when extolling the centurion's faith, how incredible a thing it is, that He should confess that He had "found so great a faith not even in Israel," to whom Israel's faith was in no way interesting! But not from the fact (here stated by Christ) could it have been of any interest to Him to approve and compare what was hitherto crude, nay, I might say, hitherto naught.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 18:6
verses.text: Why, however, might He not have used the example of faith in another god? Because, if He had done so, He would have said that no such faith had ever had existence in Israel; but as the case stands, He intimates that He ought to have found so great a faith in Israel, inasmuch as He had indeed come for the purpose of finding it, being in truth the God and Christ of Israel, and had now stigmatized it, only as one who would enforce and uphold it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 18:7
verses.text: If, indeed, He had been its antagonist, He would have preferred finding it to be such faith, having come to weaken and destroy it rather than to approve of it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 18:8
verses.text: He raised also the widow's son from death.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 18:9
verses.text: This was not a strange miracle.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 18:10
verses.text: The Creator's prophets had wrought such; then why not His Son much rather? Now, so evidently had the Lord Christ introduced no other god for the working of so momentous a miracle as this, that all who were present gave glory to the Creator, saying: "A great prophet is risen up among us, and God hath visited His people".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 18:11
verses.text: What God?  He, of course, whose people they were, and from whom had come their prophets.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 18:12
verses.text: But if they glorified the Creator, and Christ (on hearing them, and knowing their meaning) refrained from correcting them even in their very act of invoking the Creator in that vast manifestation of His glory in this raising of the dead, undoubtedly He either announced no other God but Him, whom He thus permitted to be honoured in His own beneficent acts and miracles, or else how happens it that He quietly permitted these persons to remain so long in their error, especially as He came for the very purpose to cure them of their error? But John is offended when he hears of the miracles of Christ, as of an alien god.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 18:13
verses.text: Well, I on my side will first explain the reason of his offence, that I may the more easily explode the scandal of our heretic.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 18:14
verses.text: Now, that the very Lord Himself of all might, the Word and Spirit of the Father, was operating and preaching on earth, it was necessary that the portion of the Holy Spirit which, in the form of the prophetic gift, had been through John preparing the ways of the Lord, should now depart from John, and return back again of course to the Lord, as to its all-embracing original.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 18:15
verses.text: Therefore John, being now an ordinary person, and only one of the many, was offended indeed as a man, but not because he expected or thought of another Christ as teaching or doing nothing new, for he was not even expecting such a one.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 18:16
verses.text: Nobody will entertain doubts about any one whom (since he knows him not to exist) he has no expectation or thought of.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 18:17
verses.text: Now John was quite sure that there was no other God but the Creator, even as a Jew, especially as a prophet.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 18:18
verses.text: Whatever doubt he felt was evidently rather entertained about Him whom he knew indeed to exist but knew not whether He were the very Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 18:19
verses.text: With this fear, therefore, even John asks the question, "Art thou He that should come, or look we for another?"—simply inquiring whether He was come as He whom he was looking for.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 18:20
verses.text: "Art thou He that should come?" i-e: Art thou the coming One? "or look we for another?" i-e: Is He whom we are expecting some other than Thou, if Thou art not He whom we expect to come? For he was supposing, as all men then thought, from the similarity of the miraculous evidences, that a prophet might possibly have been meanwhile sent, from whom the Lord Himself, whose coming was then expected, was different, and to whom He was superior.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 18:21
verses.text: And there lay John's difficulty.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 18:22
verses.text: He was in doubt whether He was actually come whom all men were looking for; whom, moreover, they ought to have recognised by His predicted works, even as the Lord sent word to John, that it was by means of these very works that He was to be recognised.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 18:23
verses.text: Now, inasmuch as these predictions evidently related to the Creator's Christ—as we have proved in the examination of each of them—it was perverse enough, if he gave himself out to be not the Christ of the Creator, and rested the proof of his statement on those very evidences whereby he was urging his claims to be received as the Creator's Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 18:24
verses.text: Far greater still is his perverseness when, not being the Christ of John, he yet bestows on John his testimony, affirming him to be a prophet, nay more, his messenger, applying to him the Scripture, "Behold, I send my messenger before thy face, which shall prepare thy way before thee".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 18:25
verses.text: He graciously adduced the prophecy in the superior sense of the alternative mentioned by the perplexed John, in order that, by affirming that His own precursor was already come in the person of John, He might quench the doubt which lurked in his question: "Art thou He that should come, or look we for another?"  Now that the forerunner had fulfilled his mission, and the way of the Lord was prepared, He ought now to be acknowledged as that (Christ) for whom the forerunner had made ready the way.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 18:26
verses.text: That forerunner was indeed "greater than all of women born;" but for all that, He who was least in the kingdom of God was not subject to him; as if the kingdom in which the least person was greater than John belonged to one God, while John, who was greater than all of women born, belonged himself to another God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 18:27
verses.text: For whether He speaks of any "least person" by reason of his humble position, or of Himself, as being thought to be less than John—since all were running into the wilderness after John rather than after Christ ("What went ye out into the wilderness to see?")—the Creator has equal right to claim as His own both John, greater than any born of women, and Christ, or every "least person in the kingdom of heaven," who was destined to be greater than John in that kingdom, although equally pertaining to the Creator, and who would be so much greater than the prophet, because he would not have been offended at Christ, an infirmity which then lessened the greatness of John.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 18:28
verses.text: We have already spoken of the forgiveness of sins.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 18:29
verses.text: The behaviour of "the woman which was a sinner," when she covered the Lord's feet with her kisses, bathed them with her tears, wiped them with the hairs of her head, anointed them with ointment, produced an evidence that what she handled was not an empty phantom, but a really solid body, and that her repentance as a sinner deserved forgiveness according to the mind of the Creator, who is accustomed to prefer mercy to sacrifice.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 18:30
verses.text: But even if the stimulus of her repentance proceeded from her faith, she heard her justification by faith through her repentance pronounced in the words, "Thy faith hath saved thee," by Him who had declared by Habakkuk, "The just shall live by his faith".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 19:1
verses.text: The Rich Women of Piety Who Followed Jesus Christ's Teaching by Parables.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 19:2
verses.text: The Marcionite Cavil Derived from Christ's Remark, When Told of His Mother and His Brethren.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 19:3
verses.text: Explanation of Christ's Apparent Rejection Them.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 19:4
verses.text: The fact that certain rich women clave to Christ, "which ministered unto Him of their substance," amongst whom was the wife of the king's steward, is a subject of prophecy.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 19:5
verses.text: By Isaiah the Lord called these wealthy ladies—"Rise up, ye women that are at ease, and hear my voice"—that He might prove them first as disciples, and then as assistants and helpers: "Daughters, hear my words in hope; this day of the year cherish the memory of, in labour with hope".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 19:6
verses.text: For it was "in labour" that they followed Him, and "with hope" did they minister to Him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 19:7
verses.text: On the subject of parables, let it suffice that it has been once for all shown that this kind of language was with equal distinctness promised by the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 19:8
verses.text: But there is that direct mode of His speaking to the people—"Ye shall hear with the ear, but ye shall not understand"—which now claims notice as having furnished to Christ that frequent form of His earnest instruction: "He that hath ears to hear, let him hear".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 19:9
verses.text: Not as if Christ, actuated with a diverse spirit, permitted a hearing which the Creator had refused; but because the exhortation followed the threatening.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 19:10
verses.text: First came, "Ye shall hear with the ear, but shall not understand;" then followed, "He that hath ears to hear, let him hear".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 19:11
verses.text: For they wilfully refused to hear, although they had ears.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 19:12
verses.text: He, however, was teaching them that it was the ears of the heart which were necessary; and with these the Creator had said that they would not hear.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 19:13
verses.text: Therefore it is that He adds by His Christ, "Take heed how ye hear," and hear not,—meaning, of course, with the hearing of the heart, not of the ear.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 19:14
verses.text: If you only attach a proper sense to the Creator's admonition, suitable to the meaning of Him who was rousing the people to hear by the words, "Take heed how ye hear," it amounted to a menace to such as would not hear.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 19:15
verses.text: In fact, that most merciful god of yours, who judges not, neither is angry, is minatory.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 19:16
verses.text: This is proved even by the sentence which immediately follows:  "Whosoever hath, to him shall be given; and whosoever hath not, from him shall be taken even that which he seemeth to have".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 19:17
verses.text: What shall be given? The increase of faith, or understanding, or even salvation.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 19:18
verses.text: What shall be taken away? That, of course, which shall be given.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 19:19
verses.text: By whom shall the gift and the deprivation be made? If by the Creator it be taken away, by Him also shall it be given.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 19:20
verses.text: If by Marcion's god it be given, by Marcion's god also will it be taken away.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 19:21
verses.text: Now, for whatever reason He threatens the "deprivation," it will not be the work of a god who knows not how to threaten, because incapable of anger.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 19:22
verses.text: I am, moreover, astonished when he says that "a candle is not usually hidden," who had hidden himself—a greater and more needful light—during so long a time; and when he promises that "everything shall be brought out of its secrecy and made manifest," who hitherto has kept his god in obscurity, waiting (I suppose) until Marcion be born.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 19:23
verses.text: We now come to the most strenuously-plied argument of all those who call in question the Lord's nativity.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 19:24
verses.text: They say that He testifies Himself to His not having been born, when He asks, "Who is my mother, and who are my brethren?" In this manner heretics either wrest plain and simple words to any sense they choose by their conjectures, or else they violently resolve by a literal interpretation words which imply a conditional sense and are incapable of a simple solution, as in this passage.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 19:25
verses.text: We, for our part, say in reply, first, that it could not possibly have been told Him that His mother and His brethren stood without, desiring to see Him, if He had had no mother and no brethren.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 19:26
verses.text: They must have been known to him who announced them, either some time previously, or then at that very time, when they desired to see Him, or sent Him their message.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 19:27
verses.text: To this our first position this answer is usually given by the other side.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 19:28
verses.text: But suppose they sent Him the message for the purpose of tempting Him? Well, but the Scripture does not say so; and inasmuch as it is usual for it to indicate what is done in the way of temptation ("Behold, a certain lawyer stood up, and tempted Him;" again, when inquiring about tribute, the Pharisees came to Him, tempting Him), so, when it makes no mention of temptation, it does not admit the interpretation of temptation.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 19:29
verses.text: However, although I do not allow this sense, I may as well ask, by way of a superfluous refutation, for the reasons of the alleged temptation, To what purpose could they have tempted Him by naming His mother and His brethren? If it was to ascertain whether He had been born or not—when was a question raised on this point, which they must resolve by tempting Him in this way? Who could doubt His having been born, when they saw Him before them a veritable man?—whom they had heard call Himself "Son of man?"—of whom they doubted whether He were God or Son of God, from seeing Him, as they did, in the perfect garb of human quality?—supposing Him rather to be a prophet, a great one indeed, but still one who had been born as man?  Even if it had been necessary that He should thus be tried in the investigation of His birth, surely any other proof would have better answered the trial than that to be obtained from mentioning those relatives which it was quite possible for Him, in spite of His true nativity, not at that moment to have had.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 19:30
verses.text: For tell me now, does a mother live on contemporaneously with her sons in every case? Have all sons brothers born for them? May a man rather not have fathers and sisters (living), or even no relatives at all? But there is historical proof that at this very time a census had been taken in Judaea by Sentius Saturninus, which might have satisfied their inquiry respecting the family and descent of Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 19:31
verses.text: Such a method of testing the point had therefore no consistency whatever in it and they "who were standing without" were really "His mother and His brethren".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 19:32
verses.text: It remains for us to examine His meaning when He resorts to non-literal words, saying "Who is my mother or my brethren?" It seems as if His language amounted to a denial of His family and His birth; but it arose actually from the absolute nature of the case, and the conditional sense in which His words were to be explained.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 19:33
verses.text: He was justly indignant, that persons so very near to Him "stood without," while strangers were within hanging on His words, especially as they wanted to call Him away from the solemn work He had in hand.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 19:34
verses.text: He did not so much deny as disavow them.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 19:35
verses.text: And therefore, when to the previous question, "Who is my mother, and who are my brethren? He added the answer "None but they who hear my words and do them," He transferred the names of blood-relationship to others, whom He judged to be more closely related to Him by reason of their faith.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 19:36
verses.text: Now no one transfers a thing except from him who possesses that which is transferred.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 19:37
verses.text: If, therefore, He made them "His mother and His brethren" who were not so, how could He deny them these relationships who really had them? Surely only on the condition of their deserts, and not by any disavowal of His near relatives; teaching them by His own actual example, that "whosoever preferred father or mother or brethren to the Word of God, was not a disciple worthy of Him".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 19:38
verses.text: Besides, His admission of His mother and His brethren was the more express, from the fact of His unwillingness to acknowledge them.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 19:39
verses.text: That He adopted others only confirmed those in their relationship to Him whom He refused because of their offence, and for whom He substituted the others, not as being truer relatives, but worthier ones.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 19:40
verses.text: Finally, it was no great matter if He did prefer to kindred (that) faith which it did not possess.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 20:1
verses.text: Comparison of Christ's Power Over Winds and Waves with Moses' Command of the Waters of the Red Sea and the Jordan.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 20:2
verses.text: Christ's Power Over Unclean Spirits.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 20:3
verses.text: The Case of the Legion.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 20:4
verses.text: The Cure of the Issue of Blood.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 20:5
verses.text: The Mosaic Uncleanness on This Point Explained.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 20:6
verses.text: But "what manner of man is this? for He commandeth even the winds and water!" Of course He is the new master and proprietor of the elements, now that the Creator is deposed, and excluded from their possession! Nothing of the kind.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 20:7
verses.text: But the elements own their own Maker, just as they had been accustomed to obey His servants also.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 20:8
verses.text: Examine well the Exodus, Marcion; look at the rod of Moses, as it waves His command to the Red Sea, ampler than all the lakes of Judaea.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 20:9
verses.text: How the sea yawns from its very depths, then fixes itself in two solidified masses, and so, out of the interval between them, makes a way for the people to pass dry-shod across; again does the same rod vibrate, the sea returns in its strength, and in the concourse of its waters the chivalry of Egypt is engulphed! To that consummation the very winds subserved!  Read, too, how that the Jordan was as a sword, to hinder the emigrant nation in their passage across its stream; how that its waters from above stood still, and its current below wholly ceased to run at the bidding of Joshua, when his priests began to pass over! What will you say to this? If it be your Christ that is meant above, he will not be more potent than the servants of the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 20:10
verses.text: But I should have been content with the examples I have adduced without addition, if a prediction of His present passage on the sea had not preceded Christ's coming.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 20:11
verses.text: As psalm is, in fact, accomplished by this crossing over the lake.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 20:12
verses.text: "The Lord," says the psalmist, "is upon many waters".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 20:13
verses.text: When He disperses its waves, Habakkuk's words are fulfilled, where he says, "Scattering the waters in His passage".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 20:14
verses.text: When at His rebuke the sea is calmed, Nahum is also verified: He rebuketh the sea, and maketh it dry," including the winds indeed, whereby it was disquieted.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 20:15
verses.text: With what evidence would you have my Christ vindicated? Shall it come from the examples, or from the prophecies, of the Creator? You suppose that He is predicted as a military and armed warrior, instead of one who in a figurative and allegorical sense was to wage a spiritual warfare against spiritual enemies, in spiritual campaigns, and with spiritual weapons: come now, when in one man alone you discover a multitude of demons calling itself Legion, of course comprised of spirits, you should learn that Christ also must be understood to be an exterminator of spiritual foes, who wields spiritual arms and fights in spiritual strife; and that it was none other than He, who now had to contend with even a legion of demons.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 20:16
verses.text: Therefore it is of such a war as this that the Psalm may evidently have spoken:  "The Lord is strong, The Lord is mighty in battle".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 20:17
verses.text: For with the last enemy death did He fight, and through the trophy of the cross He triumphed.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 20:18
verses.text: Now of what God did the Legion testify that Jesus was the Son? No doubt, of that God whose torments and abyss they knew and dreaded.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 20:19
verses.text: It seems impossible for them to have remained up to this time in ignorance of what the power of the recent and unknown god was working in the world, because it is very unlikely that the Creator was ignorant thereof.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 20:20
verses.text: For if He had been at any time ignorant that there was another god above Himself, He had by this time at all events discovered that there was one at work below His heaven.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 20:21
verses.text: Now, what their Lord had discovered had by this time become notorious to His entire family within the same world and the same circuit of heaven, in which the strange deity dwelt and acted.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 20:22
verses.text: As therefore both the Creator and His creatures must have had knowledge of him, if he had been in existence, so, inasmuch as he had no existence, the demons really knew none other than the Christ of their own God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 20:23
verses.text: They do not ask of the strange god, what they recollected they must beg of the Creator—not to be plunged into the Creator's abyss.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 20:24
verses.text: They at last had their request granted.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 20:25
verses.text: On what ground? Because they had lied? Because they had proclaimed Him to be the Son of a ruthless God? And what sort of god will that be who helped the lying, and upheld his detractors? However, no need of this thought, for, inasmuch as they had not lied, inasmuch as they had acknowledged that the God of the abyss was also their God, so did He actually Himself affirm that He was the same whom these demons acknowledged—Jesus, the Judge and Son of the avenging God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 20:26
verses.text: Now, behold an inkling of the Creator's failings and infirmities in Christ; for I on my side mean to impute to Him ignorance.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 20:27
verses.text: Allow me some indulgence in my effort against the heretic.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 20:28
verses.text: Jesus is touched by the woman who had an issue of blood, He knew not by whom.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 20:29
verses.text: "Who touched me?" He asks, when His disciples alleged an excuse.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 20:30
verses.text: He even persists in His assertion of ignorance: "Somebody hath touched me," He says, and advances some proof: "For I perceive that virtue is gone out of me".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 20:31
verses.text: What says our heretic? Could Christ have known the person? And why did He speak as if He were ignorant? Why? Surely it was to challenge her faith, and to try her fear.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 20:32
verses.text: Precisely as He had once questioned Adam, as if in ignorance:  Adam, where art thou?" Thus you have both the Creator excused in the same way as Christ, and Christ acting similarly to the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 20:33
verses.text: But in this case He acted as an adversary of the law; and therefore, as the law forbids contact with a woman with an issue, He desired not only that this woman should touch Him, but that He should heal her.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 20:34
verses.text: Here, then, is a God who is not merciful by nature, but in hostility!  Yet, if we find that such was the merit of this woman's faith, that He said unto her, Thy faith hath saved thee," what are you, that you should detect an hostility to the law in that act, which the Lord Himself shows us to have been done as a reward of faith? But will you have it that this faith of the woman consisted in the contempt which she had acquired for the law? Who can suppose, that a woman who had been.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 20:35
verses.text: hitherto unconscious of any God, uninitiated as yet in any new law, should violently infringe that law by which she was up to this time bound? On what faith, indeed, was such an infringement hazarded? In what God believing? Whom despising? The Creator?  Her touch at least was an act of faith.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 20:36
verses.text: And if of faith in the Creator, how could she have violated His law, when she was ignorant of any other God?  Whatever her infringement of the law amounted to, it proceeded from and was proportionate to her faith in the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 20:37
verses.text: But how can these two things be compatible? That she violated the law, and violated it in faith, which ought to have restrained her from such violation? I will tell you how her faith was this above all: it made her believe that her God preferred mercy even to sacrifice; she was certain that her God was working in Christ; she touched Him, therefore, nor as a holy man simply, nor as a prophet, whom she knew to be capable of contamination by reason of his human nature, but as very God, whom she assumed to be beyond all possibility of pollution by any uncleanness.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 20:38
verses.text: She therefore, not without reason, interpreted for herself the law, as meaning that such things as are susceptible of defilement become defiled, but not so God, whom she knew for certain to be in Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 20:39
verses.text: But she recollected this also, that what came under the prohibition of the law was that ordinary and usual issue of blood which proceeds from natural functions every month, and in childbirth, not that which was the result of disordered health.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 20:40
verses.text: Her case, however, was one of long abounding ill health, for which she knew that the succour of God's mercy was needed, and not the natural relief of time.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 20:41
verses.text: And thus she may evidently be regarded as having discerned the law, instead of breaking it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 20:42
verses.text: This will prove to be the faith which was to confer intelligence likewise.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 20:43
verses.text: "If ye will not believe," says (the prophet), "ye shall not understand".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 20:44
verses.text: When Christ approved of the faith of this woman, which simply rested in the Creator, He declared by His answer to her, that He was Himself the divine object of the faith of which He approved.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 20:45
verses.text: Nor can I overlook the fact that His garment, by being touched, demonstrated also the truth of His body; for of course" it was a body, and not a phantom, which the garment clothed.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 20:46
verses.text: This indeed is not our point now; but the remark has a natural bearing on the question we are discussing.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 20:47
verses.text: For if it were not a veritable body, but only a fantastic one, it could not for certain have received contamination, as being an unsubstantial thing.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 20:48
verses.text: He therefore, who, by reason of this vacuity of his substance, was incapable of contamination, how could he possibly have desired this touch? As an adversary of the law, his conduct was deceitful, for he was not susceptible of a real pollution.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 21:1
verses.text: Christ's Connection with the Creator Shown from Several Incidents in the Old Testament, Compared with St.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 21:2
verses.text: Luke's Narrative of the Mission of the Disciples.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 21:3
verses.text: The Feeding of the Multitude.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 21:4
verses.text: The Confession of St.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 21:5
verses.text: Peter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 21:6
verses.text: Being Ashamed of Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 21:7
verses.text: This Shame is Only Possible of the True Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 21:8
verses.text: Marcionite Pretensions Absurd.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 21:9
verses.text: He sends forth His disciples to preach the kingdom of God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 21:10
verses.text: Does He here say of what God? He forbids their taking anything for their journey, by way of either food or raiment.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 21:11
verses.text: Who would have given such a commandment as this, but He who feeds the ravens and clothes the flowers of the field? Who anciently enjoined for the treading ox an unmuzzled mouth, that he might be at liberty to gather his fodder from his labour, on the principle that the worker is worthy of his hire? Marcion may expunge such precepts, but no matter, provided the sense of them survives.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 21:12
verses.text: But when He charges them to shake off the dust of their feet against such as should refuse to receive them, He also bids that this be done as a witness.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 21:13
verses.text: Now no one bears witness except in a case which is decided by judicial process; and whoever orders inhuman conduct to be submitted to the trial by testimony, does really threaten as a judge.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 21:14
verses.text: Again, that it was no new god which recommended by Christ, was clearly attested by the opinion of all men, because some maintained to Herod that Jesus was the Christ; others, that He was John; some, that He was Elias; and others, that He was one of the old prophets.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 21:15
verses.text: Now, whosoever of all these He might have been, He certainly was not raised up for the purpose of announcing another god after His resurrection.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 21:16
verses.text: He feeds the multitude in the desert place; this, you must know was after the manner of the Old Testament.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 21:17
verses.text: Or else, if there was not the same grandeur, it follows that He is now inferior to the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 21:18
verses.text: For He, not for one day, but during forty years, not on the inferior aliment of bread and fish, but with the manna of heaven, supported the lives of not five thousand, but of six hundred thousand human beings.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 21:19
verses.text: However, such was the greatness of His miracle, that He willed the slender supply of food, not only to be enough, but even to prove superabundant; and herein He followed the ancient precedent.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 21:20
verses.text: For in like manner, during the famine in Elijah's time, the scanty and final meal of the widow of Sarepta was multiplied by the blessing of the prophet throughout the period of the famine.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 21:21
verses.text: You have the third book of the Kings.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 21:22
verses.text: If you also turn to the fourth book, you will discover all this conduct of Christ pursued by that man of God, who ordered ten barley loaves which had been given him to be distributed among the people; and when his servitor, after contrasting the large number of the persons with the small supply of the food, answered, "What, shall I set this before a hundred men?" he said again, "Give them, and they shall eat: for thus saith the Lord, They shall eat, and shall leave thereof, according to the word of the Lord".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 21:23
verses.text: O Christ, even in Thy novelties Thou art old! Accordingly, when Peter, who had been an eye-witness of the miracle, and had compared it with the ancient precedents, and had discovered in them prophetic intimations of what should one day come to pass, answered (as the mouthpiece of them all) the Lord's inquiry, "Whom say ye that I am?" in the words, "Thou art the Christ," he could not but have perceived that He was that Christ, beside whom he knew of none else in the Scriptures, and whom he was now surveying in His wonderful deeds.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 21:24
verses.text: This conclusion He even Himself confirms by thus far bearing with it, nay, even enjoining silence respecting it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 21:25
verses.text: For if Peter was unable to acknowledge Him to be any other than the Creator's Christ, while He commanded them "to tell no man that saying," surely He was unwilling to have the conclusion promulged which Peter had drawn.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 21:26
verses.text: No doubt of that, you say; but as Peter's conclusion was a wrong one, therefore He was unwilling to have a lie disseminated.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 21:27
verses.text: It was, however, a different reason which He assigned for the silence, even because "the Son of man must suffer many things, and be rejected of the elders, and scribes, and priests, and be slain, and be raised again the third day".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 21:28
verses.text: Now, inasmuch as these sufferings were actually foretold for the Creator's Christ (as we shall fully show in the proper place), so by this application of them to His own case does He prove that it is He Himself of whom they were predicted.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 21:29
verses.text: At all events, even if they had not been predicted, the reason which He alleged for imposing silence (on the disciples) was such as made it clear enough that Peter had made no mistake, that reason being the necessity of His undergoing these sufferings.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 21:30
verses.text: "Whosoever," says He, "will save his life, shall lose it; and whosoever will lose his life for my sake, the same shall save it".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 21:31
verses.text: Surely it is the Son of man who uttered this sentence.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 21:32
verses.text: Look carefully, then, along with the king of Babylon, into his burning fiery furnace, and there you will discover one "like the Son of man" (for He was not yet really Son of man, because not yet born of man), even as early as then appointing issues such as these.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 21:33
verses.text: He saved the lives of the three brethren, who had agreed to lose them for God's sake; but He destroyed those of the Chaldaeans, when they had preferred to save them by the means of their idolatry.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 21:34
verses.text: Where is that novelty, which you pretend in a doctrine which possesses these ancient proofs? But all the predictions have been fulfilled concerning martyrdoms which were to happen, and were to receive the recompenses of their reward from God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 21:35
verses.text: "See," says Isaiah, "how the righteous perisheth, and no man layeth it to heart; and just men are taken away, and no man considereth".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 21:36
verses.text: When does this more frequently happen than in the persecution of His saints? This, indeed, is no ordinary matter, no common casualty of the law of nature; but it is that illustrious devotion, that fighting for the faith, wherein whosoever loses his life for God saves it, so that you may here again recognize the Judge who recompenses the evil gain of life with its destruction, and the good loss thereof with its salvation.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 21:37
verses.text: It is, however, a jealous God whom He here presents to me; one who returns evil for evil.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 21:38
verses.text: "For whosoever," says He, "shall be ashamed of me, of him will I also be ashamed".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 21:39
verses.text: Now to none but my Christ can be assigned the occasion of such a shame as this.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 21:40
verses.text: His whole course was so exposed to shame as to open a way for even the taunts of heretics, declaiming with all the bitterness in their power against the utter disgrace of His birth and bringing-up, and the unworthiness of His very flesh.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 21:41
verses.text: But how can that Christ of yours be liable to a shame, which it is impossible for him to experience? Since he was never condensed into human flesh in the womb of a woman, although a virgin; never grew from human seed, although only after the law of corporeal substance, from the fluids of a woman; was never deemed flesh before shaped in the womb; never called foetus after such shaping; was never delivered from a ten months' writhing in the womb; was never shed forth upon the ground, amidst the sudden pains of parturition, with the unclean issue which flows at such a time through the sewerage of the body, forthwith to inaugurate the light of life with tears, and with that primal wound which severs the child from her who bears him; never received the copious ablution, nor the meditation of salt and honey; nor did he initiate a shroud with swaddling clothes; nor afterwards did he ever wallow in his own uncleanness, in his mother's lap; nibbling at her breast; long an infant; gradually a boy; by slow degrees a man.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 21:42
verses.text: But he was revealed from heaven, full-grown at once, at once complete; immediately Christ; simply spirit, and power, and god.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 21:43
verses.text: But as withal he was not true, because not visible; therefore he was no object to be ashamed of from the curse of the cross, the real endurance of which he escaped, because wanting in bodily substance.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 21:44
verses.text: Never, therefore, could he have said, "Whosoever shall be ashamed of me".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 21:45
verses.text: But as for our Christ, He could do no otherwise than make such a declaration; "made" by the Father "a little lower than the angels," "a worm and no man, a reproach of men, and despised of the people;" seeing that it was His will that "with His stripes we should be healed," that by His humiliation our salvation should be established.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 21:46
verses.text: And justly did He humble Himself for His own creature man, for the image and likeness of Himself, and not of another, in order that man, since he had not felt ashamed when bowing down to a stone or a stock, might with similar courage give satisfaction to God for the shamelessness of his idolatry, by displaying an equal degree of shamelessness in his faith, in not being ashamed of Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 21:47
verses.text: Now, Marcion, which of these courses is better suited to your Christ, in respect of a meritorious shame? Plainly, you ought yourself to blush with shame for having given him a fictitious existence.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:1
verses.text: The Same Conclusion Supported by the Transfiguration.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:2
verses.text: Marcion Inconsistent in Associating with Christ in Glory Two Such Eminent Servants of the Creator as Moses and Elijah.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:3
verses.text: St.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:4
verses.text: Peter's Ignorance Accounted for on Montanist Principle.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:5
verses.text: You ought to be very much ashamed of yourself on this account too, for permitting him to appear on the retired mountain in the company of Moses and Elias, whom he had come to destroy.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:6
verses.text: This, to be sure, was what he wished to be understood as the meaning of that voice from heaven: "This is my beloved Son, hear Him"—Him, that is, not Moses or Elias any longer.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:7
verses.text: The voice alone, therefore, was enough, without the display of Moses and Elias; for, by expressly mentioning whom they were to hear, he must have forbidden all others from being heard.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:8
verses.text: Or else, did he mean that Isaiah and Jeremiah and the others whom he did not exhibit were to be heard, since he prohibited those whom he did display? Now, even if their presence was necessary, they surely should not be represented as conversing together, which is a sign of familiarity; nor as associated in glory with him, for this indicates respect and graciousness; but they should be shown in some slough as a sure token of their ruin, or even in that darkness of the Creator which Christ was sent to disperse, far removed from the glory of Him who was about to sever their words and writings from His gospel.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:9
verses.text: This, then, is the way how he demonstrates them to be aliens, even by keeping them in his own company!  This is how he shows they ought to be relinquished: he associates them with himself instead! This is how he destroys them: he irradiates them with his glory! How would their own Christ act? I suppose He would have imitated the frowardness (of heresy), and revealed them just as Marcion's Christ was bound to do, or at least as having with Him any others rather than His own prophets! But what could so well befit the Creator's Christ, as to manifest Him in the company of His own foreannouncers?—to let Him be seen with those to whom He had appeared in revelations?—to let Him be speaking with those who had spoken of Him?—to share His glory with those by whom He used to be called the Lord of glory; even with those chief servants of His, one of whom was once the moulder of His people, the other afterwards the reformer thereof; one the initiator of the Old Testament, the other the consummator of the New? Well therefore does Peter, when recognizing the companions of his Christ in their indissoluble connection with Him, suggest an expedient: "It is good for us to be here" (good: that evidently means to be where Moses and Elias are); "and let us make three tabernacles, one for Thee, and one for Moses, and one for Elias.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:10
verses.text: But he knew not what he said".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:11
verses.text: How knew not?  Was his ignorance the result of simple error? Or was it on the principle which we maintain in the cause of the new prophecy, that to grace ecstasy or rapture is incident.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:12
verses.text: For when a man is rapt in the Spirit, especially when he beholds the glory of God, or when God speaks through him, he necessarily loses his sensation, because he is overshadowed with the power of God,—a point concerning which there is a question between us and the carnally-minded.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:13
verses.text: Now, it is no difficult matter to prove the rapture of Peter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:14
verses.text: For how could he have known Moses and Elias, except (by being) in the Spirit? People could not have had their images, or statues, or likenesses; for that the law forbade.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:15
verses.text: How, if it were not that he had seen them in the Spirit? And therefore, because it was in the Spirit that he had now spoken, and not in his natural senses, he could not know what he had said.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:16
verses.text: But if, on the other hand, he was thus ignorant, because he erroneously supposed that (Jesus) was their Christ, it is then evident that Peter, when previously asked by Christ, "Whom they thought Him to be," meant the Creator's Christ, when he answered, "Thou art the Christ;" because if he had been then aware that He belonged to the rival god, he would not have made a mistake here.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:17
verses.text: But if he was in error here because of his previous erroneous opinion, then you may be sure that up to that very day no new divinity had been revealed by Christ, and that Peter had so far made no mistake, because hitherto Christ had revealed nothing of the kind; and that Christ accordingly was not to be regarded as belonging to any other than the Creator, whose entire dispensation he, in fact, here described.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:18
verses.text: He selects from His disciples three witnesses of the impending vision and voice.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:19
verses.text: And this is just the way of the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:20
verses.text: "In the mouth of three witnesses," says He, "shall every word be established".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:21
verses.text: He withdraws to a mountain.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:22
verses.text: In the nature of the place I see much meaning.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:23
verses.text: For the Creator had originally formed His ancient people on a mountain both with visible glory and His voice.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:24
verses.text: It was only right that the New Testament should be attested on such an elevated spot as that whereon the Old Testament had been composed; under a like covering of cloud also, which nobody will doubt, was condensed out of the Creator's air.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:25
verses.text: Unless, indeed, he had brought down his own clouds thither, because he had himself forced his way through the Creator's heaven; or else it was only a precarious cloud, as it were, of the Creator which he used.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:26
verses.text: On the present (as also on the former) occasion, therefore, the cloud was not silent; but there was the accustomed voice from heaven, and the Father's testimony to the Son; precisely as in the first Psalm He had said, "Thou art my Son, today have I begotten thee".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:27
verses.text: By the mouth of Isaiah also He had asked concerning Him, "Who is there among you that feareth God? Let him hear the voice of His Son".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:28
verses.text: When therefore He here presents Him with the words, "This is my (beloved) Son," this clause is of course understood, "whom I have promised".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:29
verses.text: For if He once promised, and then afterwards says, "This is He," it is suitable conduct for one who accomplishes His purpose that He should utter His voice in proof of the promise which He had formerly made; but unsuitable in one who is amenable to the retort, Can you, indeed, have a right to say, "This is my son," concerning whom you have given us no previous information, any more than you have favoured us with a revelation about your own prior existence? "Hear ye Him," therefore, whom from the beginning (the Creator) had declared entitled to be heard in the name of a prophet, since it was as a prophet that He had to be regarded by the people.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:30
verses.text: "A prophet," says Moses, "shall the Lord your God raise up unto you, of your sons" (that is, of course, after a carnal descent); "unto Him shall ye hearken, as unto me".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:31
verses.text: "Every one who will not hearken unto Him, his soul shall be cut off from amongst his people".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:32
verses.text: So also Isaiah: "Who is there among you that feareth God? Let him hear the voice of His Son".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:33
verses.text: This voice the Father was going Himself to recommend.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:34
verses.text: For, says he, He establishes the words of His Son, when He says, "This is my beloved Son, hear ye Him".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:35
verses.text: Therefore, even if there be made a transfer of the obedient "hearing" from Moses and Elias to Christ, it is still not from another God, or to another Christ; but from the Creator to His Christ, in consequence of the departure of the old covenant and the supervening of the new.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:36
verses.text: "Not an ambassador, nor an angel, but He Himself," says Isaiah, "shall save them;" for it is He Himself who is now declaring and fulfilling the law and the prophets.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:37
verses.text: The Father gave to the Son new disciples, after that Moses and Elias had been exhibited along with Him in the honour of His glory, and had then been dismissed as having fully discharged their duty and office, for the express purpose of affirming for Marcion's information the fact that Moses and Elias had a share in even the glory of Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:38
verses.text: But we have the entire structure of this same vision in Habakkuk also, where the Spirit in the person of some of the apostles says, "O Lord, I have heard Thy speech, and was afraid".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:39
verses.text: What speech was this, other than the words of the voice from heaven, This is my beloved Son, hear ye Him? "I considered thy works, and was astonished".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:40
verses.text: When could this have better happened than when Peter, on seeing His glory, knew not what he was saying? "In the midst of the two Thou shalt be known"—even Moses and Elias.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:41
verses.text: These likewise did Zechariah see under the figure of the two olive trees and olive branches.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:42
verses.text: For these are they of whom he says, "They are the two anointed ones, that stand by the Lord of the whole earth".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:43
verses.text: And again Habakkuk says, "His glory covered the heavens" (that is, with that cloud), "and His splendour shall be like the light—even the light, wherewith His very raiment glistened".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:44
verses.text: And if we would make mention of the promise to Moses, we shall find it accomplished here.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:45
verses.text: For when Moses desired to see the Lord, saying, "If therefore I have found grace in Thy sight, manifest Thyself to me, that I may see Thee distinctly," the sight which he desired to have was of that condition which he was to assume as man, and which as a prophet he knew was to occur.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:46
verses.text: Respecting the face of God, however, he had already heard, "No man shall see me, and live".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:47
verses.text: "This thing," said He, "which thou hast spoken, will I do unto thee".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:48
verses.text: Then Moses said, "Show me Thy glory".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:49
verses.text: And the Lord, with like reference to the future, replied, "I will pass before thee in my glory," etc.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:50
verses.text: Then at the last He says, "And then thou shalt see my back".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:51
verses.text: Not loins, or calves of the legs, did he want to behold, but the glory which was to be revealed in the latter days.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:52
verses.text: He had promised that He would make Himself thus face to face visible to him, when He said to Aaron, "If there shall be a prophet among you, I will make myself known to him by vision, and by vision will I speak with him; but not so is my manner to Moses; with him will I speak mouth to mouth, even apparently" (that is to say, in the form of man which He was to assume), "and not in dark speeches".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:53
verses.text: Now, although Marcion has denied that he is here represented as speaking with the Lord, but only as standing, yet, inasmuch as he stood "mouth to mouth," he must also have stood "face to face" with him, to use his words, not far from him, in His very glory—not to say, in His presence.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 22:54
verses.text: And with this glory he went away enlightened from Christ, just as he used to do from the Creator; as then to dazzle the eyes of the children of Israel, so now to smite those of the blinded Marcion, who has failed to see how this argument also makes against him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 23:1
verses.text: Impossible that Marcion's Christ Should Reprove the Faithless Generation.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 23:2
verses.text: Such Loving Consideration for Infants as the True Christ Was Apt to Shew, Also Impossible for the Other.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 23:3
verses.text: On the Three Different Characters Confronted and Instructed by Christ in Samaria.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 23:4
verses.text: I take on myself the character of Israel.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 23:5
verses.text: Let Marcion's Christ stand forth, and exclaim, "O faithless generation! how long shall I be with you? how long shall I suffer you?" He will immediately have to submit to this remonstrance from me: "Whoever you are, O stranger, first tell us who you are, from whom you come, and what right you have over us.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 23:6
verses.text: Thus far, all you possess belongs to the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 23:7
verses.text: Of course, if you come from Him, and are acting for Him, we will bear your reproof.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 23:8
verses.text: But if you come from some other god, I should wish you to tell us what you have ever committed to us belonging to yourself, which it was our duty to believe, seeing that you are upbraiding us with 'faithlessness,' who have never yet revealed to us your own self.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 23:9
verses.text: How long ago did you begin to treat with us, that you should be complaining of the delay? On what points have you borne with us, that you should adduce your patience? Like aesop's ass, you are just come from the well, and are filling every place with your braying".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 23:10
verses.text: I assume, besides, the person of the disciple, against whom he has inveighed: "O perverse nation! how long shall I be with you? how long shall I suffer you?" This outburst of his I might, of course, retort upon him most justly in such words as these: "Whoever you are, O stranger, first tell us who you are, from whom you come, what right you have over us.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 23:11
verses.text: Thus far, I suppose, you belong to the Creator, and so we have followed you, recognising in you all things which are His.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 23:12
verses.text: Now, if you come from Him, we will bear your reproof.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 23:13
verses.text: If, however, you are acting for another, prythee tell us what you have ever conferred upon us that is simply your own, which it had become our duty to believe, seeing that you reproach us with 'faithlessness,' although up to this moment you show us no credentials.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 23:14
verses.text: How long since did you begin to plead with us, that you are charging us with delay? Wherein have you borne with us, that you should even boast of your patience? The ass has only just arrived from aesop's well, and he is already braying".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 23:15
verses.text: Now who would not thus have rebutted the unfairness of the rebuke, if he had supposed its author to belong to him who had had no right as yet to complain?  Except that not even He would have inveighed against them, if He had not dwelt among them of old in the law and by the prophets, and with mighty deeds and many mercies, and had always experienced them to be "faithless".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 23:16
verses.text: But, behold, Christ takes infants, and teaches how all ought to be like them, if they ever wish to be greater.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 23:17
verses.text: The Creator, on the contrary, let loose bears against children, in order to avenge His prophet Elisha, who had been mocked by them.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 23:18
verses.text: This antithesis is impudent enough, since it throws together things so different as infants and children,—an age still innocent, and one already capable of discretion—able to mock, if not to blaspheme.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 23:19
verses.text: As therefore God is a just God, He spared not impious children, exacting as He does honour for every time of life, and especially, of course, from youth.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 23:20
verses.text: And as God is good, He so loves infants as to have blessed the midwives in Egypt, when they protected the infants of the Hebrews which were in peril from Pharaoh's command.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 23:21
verses.text: Christ therefore shares this kindness with the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 23:22
verses.text: As indeed for Marcion's god, who is an enemy to marriage, how can he possibly seem to be a lover of little children, which are simply the issue of marriage? He who hates the seed must needs also detest the fruit.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 23:23
verses.text: Yea, he ought to be deemed more ruthless than the king of Egypt.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 23:24
verses.text: For whereas Pharaoh forbade infants to be brought up, he will not allow them even to be born, depriving them of their ten months' existence in the womb.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 23:25
verses.text: And how much more credible it is, that kindness to little children should be attributed to Him who blessed matrimony for the procreation of mankind, and in such benediction included also the promise of connubial fruit itself, the first of which is that of infancy! The Creator, at the request of Elias, inflicts the blow of fire from heaven in the case of that false prophet (of Baalzebub).

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 23:26
verses.text: I recognise herein the severity of the Judge.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 23:27
verses.text: And I, on the contrary, the severe rebuke of Christ on His disciples, when they were for inflicting a like visitation on that obscure village of the Samaritans.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 23:28
verses.text: The heretic, too, may discover that this gentleness of Christ was promised by the selfsame severest Judge.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 23:29
verses.text: "He shall not contend," says He, "nor shall His voice be heard in the street; a bruised reed shall He not crush, and smoking flax shall He not quench".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 23:30
verses.text: Being of such a character, He was of course much the less disposed to burn men.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 23:31
verses.text: For even at that time the Lord said to Elias, "He was not in the fire, but in the still small voice".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 23:32
verses.text: Well, but why does this most humane and merciful God reject the man who offers himself to Him as an inseparable companion? If it were from pride or from hypocrisy that he had said, "I will follow Thee whithersoever Thou goest,' then, by judicially reproving an act of either pride or hypocrisy as worthy of rejection, He performed the office of a Judge.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 23:33
verses.text: And, of course, him whom He rejected He condemned to the loss of not following the Saviour.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 23:34
verses.text: For as He calls to salvation him whom He does not reject, or him whom He voluntarily invites, so does He consign to perdition him whom He rejects.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 23:35
verses.text: When, however, He answers the man, who alleged as an excuse his father's burial, "Let the dead bury their dead, but go thou and preach the kingdom of God," He gave a clear confirmation to those two laws of the Creator—that in Leviticus, which concerns the sacerdotal office, and forbids the priests to be present at the funerals even of their parents.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 23:36
verses.text: "The priest," says He, "shall not enter where there is any dead person; and for his father he shall not be defiled"; as well as that in Numbers, which relates to the (Nazarite) vow of separation; for there he who devotes himself to God, among other things, is bidden "not to come at any dead body," not even of his father, or his mother, or his brother.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 23:37
verses.text: Now it was, I suppose, for the Nazarite and the priestly office that He intended this man whom He had been inspiring to preach the kingdom of God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 23:38
verses.text: Or else, if it be not so, he must be pronounced impious enough who, without the intervention of any precept of the law, commanded that burials of parents should be neglected by their sons.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 23:39
verses.text: When, indeed, in the third case before us, (Christ) forbids the man "to look back" who wanted first "to bid his family farewell," He only follows out the rule of the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 23:40
verses.text: For this (retrospection) He had been against their making, whom He had rescued out of Sodom.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 24:1
verses.text: On the Mission of the Seventy Disciples, and Christ's Charge to Them.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 24:2
verses.text: Precedents Drawn from the Old Testament.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 24:3
verses.text: Absurdity of Supposing that Marcion's Christ Could Have Given the Power of Treading on Serpents and Scorpions.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 24:4
verses.text: He chose also seventy other missionaries besides the twelve.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 24:5
verses.text: Now why, if the twelve followed the number of the twelve fountains of Elim, should not the seventy correspond to the like number of the palms of that place?
