Whatever be the Antitheses of the comparison, it is a diversity in the causes, not in the powers, which has mainly produced them.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 24:6
verses.text: But if one does not keep in view the diversity of the causes, he is very apt to infer a difference of powers.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 24:7
verses.text: When the children of Israel went out of Egypt, the Creator brought them forth laden with their spoils of gold and silver vessels, and with loads besides of raiment and unleavened dough; whereas Christ commanded His disciples not to carry even a staff for their journey.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 24:8
verses.text: The former were thrust forth into a desert, but the latter were sent into cities.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 24:9
verses.text: Consider the difference presented in the occasions, and you will understand how it was one and the same power which arranged the mission of His people according to their poverty in the one case, and their plenty in the other.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 24:10
verses.text: He cut down their supplies when they could be replenished through the cities, just as He had accumulated them when exposed to the scantiness of the desert.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 24:11
verses.text: Even shoes He forbade them to carry.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 24:12
verses.text: For it was He under whose very protection the people wore not out a shoe, even in the wilderness for the space of so many years.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 24:13
verses.text: "No one," says He, "shall ye salute by the way".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 24:14
verses.text: What a destroyer of the prophets, forsooth, is Christ, seeing it is from them that He received his precept also! When Elisha sent on his servant Gehazi before him to raise the Shunammite's son from death, I rather think he gave him these instructions: "Gird up thy loins, and take my staff in thine hand, and go thy way: if thou meet any man, salute him not; and if any salute thee, answer him not again".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 24:15
verses.text: For what is a wayside blessing but a mutual salutation as men meet? So also the Lord commands: "Into whatsoever house they enter, let them say, Peace be to it".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 24:16
verses.text: Herein He follows the very same example.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 24:17
verses.text: For Elisha enjoined upon his servant the same salutation when he met the Shunammite; he was to say to her: "Peace to thine husband, peace to thy child".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 24:18
verses.text: Such will be rather our Antitheses; they compare Christ with, instead of sundering Him from, the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 24:19
verses.text: "The labourer is worthy of his hire".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 24:20
verses.text: Who could better pronounce such a sentence than the Judge? For to decide that the workman deserves his wages, is in itself a judicial act.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 24:21
verses.text: There is no award which consists not in a process of judgment.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 24:22
verses.text: The law of the Creator on this point also presents us with a corroboration, for He judges that labouring oxen are as labourers worthy of their hire: "Thou shalt not muzzle," says He, "the ox when he treadeth out the corn".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 24:23
verses.text: Now, who is so good to man as He who is also merciful to cattle?  Now, when Christ pronounced labourers to be worthy of their hire, He, in fact, exonerated from blame that precept of the Creator about depriving the Egyptians of their gold and silver vessels.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 24:24
verses.text: For they who had built for the Egyptians their houses and cities, were surely workmen worthy of their hire, and were not instructed in a fraudulent act, but only set to claim compensation for their hire, which they were unable in any other way to exact from their masters.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 24:25
verses.text: That the kingdom of God was neither new nor unheard of, He in this way affirmed, whilst at the same time He bids them announce that it was near at hand.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 24:26
verses.text: Now it is that which was once far off, which can be properly said to have become near.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 24:27
verses.text: If, however, a thing had never existed previous to its becoming near, it could never have been said to have approached, because it had never existed at a distance.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 24:28
verses.text: Everything which is new and unknown is also sudden.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 24:29
verses.text: Everything which is sudden, then, first receives the accident of time when it is announced, for it then first puts on appearance of form.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 24:30
verses.text: Besides it will be impossible for a thing either to have been tardy all the while it remained unannounced, or to have approached from the time it shall begin to be announced.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 24:31
verses.text: He likewise adds, that they should say to such as would not receive them: "Notwithstanding be ye sure of this, that the kingdom of God is come nigh unto you".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 24:32
verses.text: If He does not enjoin this by way of a commination, the injunction is a most useless one.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 24:33
verses.text: For what mattered it to them that the kingdom was at hand, unless its approach was accompanied with judgment?—even for the salvation of such as received the announcement thereof.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 24:34
verses.text: How, if there can be a threat without its accomplishment, can you have in a threatening god, one that executes also, and in both, one that is a judicial being? So, again, He commands that the dust be shaken off against them, as a testimony,—the very particles of their ground which might cleave to the sandal, not to mention any other sort of communication with them.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 24:35
verses.text: But if their churlishness and inhospitality were to receive no vengeance from Him, for what purpose does He premise a testimony, which surely forbodes some threats? Furthermore, when the Creator also, in the book of Deuteronomy, forbids the reception of the Ammonites and the Moabites into the church, because, when His people came from Egypt, they fraudulently withheld provisions from them with inhumanity and inhospitality, it will be manifest that the prohibition of intercourse descended to Christ from Him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 24:36
verses.text: The form of it which He uses—"He that despiseth you, despiseth me"—the Creator had also addressed to Moses:  "Not against thee have they murmured, but against me".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 24:37
verses.text: Moses, indeed, was as much an apostle as the apostles were prophets.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 24:38
verses.text: The authority of both offices will have to be equally divided, as it proceeds from one and the same Lord, (the God) of apostles and prophets.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 24:39
verses.text: Who is He that shall bestow "the power of treading on serpents and scorpions?" Shall it be He who is the Lord of all living creatures or he who is not god over a single lizard? Happily the Creator has promised by Isaiah to give this power even to little children, of putting their hand in the cockatrice den and on the hole of the young asps without at all receiving hurt.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 24:40
verses.text: And, indeed, we are aware (without doing violence to the literal sense of the passage, since even these noxious animals have actually been unable to do hurt where there has been faith) that under the figure of scorpions and serpents are portended evil spirits, whose very prince is described by the name of serpent, dragon, and every other most conspicuous beast in the power of the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 24:41
verses.text: This power the Creator conferred first of all upon His Christ, even as the ninetieth Psalm says to Him: "Upon the asp and the basilisk shalt Thou tread; the lion and the dragon shalt Thou trample under foot".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 24:42
verses.text: So also Isaiah: "In that day the Lord God shall draw His sacred, great, and strong sword" (even His Christ) "against that dragon, that great and tortuous serpent; and He shall slay him in that day".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 24:43
verses.text: But when the same prophet says, "The way shall be called a clean and holy way; over it the unclean thing shall not pass, nor shall be there any unclean way; but the dispersed shall pass over it, and they shall not err therein; no lion shall be there, nor any ravenous beast shall go up thereon; it shall not be found there," he points out the way of faith, by which we shall reach to God; and then to this way of faith he promises this utter crippling and subjugation of all noxious animals.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 24:44
verses.text: Lastly, you may discover the suitable times of the promise, if you read what precedes the passage: "Be strong, ye weak hands and ye feeble knees: then the eyes of the blind shall be opened, and the ears of the deaf shall hear; then shall the lame man leap as an hart, and the tongue of the dumb shall be articulate".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 24:45
verses.text: When, therefore, He proclaimed the benefits of His cures, then also did He put the scorpions and the serpents under the feet of His saints—even He who had first received this power from the Father, in order to bestow it upon others and then manifested it forth conformably to the order of prophecy.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:1
verses.text: Christ Thanks the Father for Revealing to Babes What He Had Concealed from the Wise.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:2
verses.text: This Concealment Judiciously Effected by the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:3
verses.text: Other Points in St.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:4
verses.text: Luke's Chap.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:5
verses.text: X.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:6
verses.text: Shown to Be Only Possible to the Creator's Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:7
verses.text: Who shall be invoked as the Lord of heaven, that does not first show Himself to have been the maker thereof? For He says, "I thank thee, (O Father,) and own Thee, Lord of heaven, because those things which had been hidden from the wise and prudent, Thou has revealed unto babes".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:8
verses.text: What things are these? And whose?  And by whom hidden? And by whom revealed? If it was by Marcion's god that they were hidden and revealed, it was an extremely iniquitous proceeding; for nothing at all had he ever produced in which anything could have been hidden—no prophecies, no parables, no visions, no evidences of things, or words, or names, obscured by allegories and figures, or cloudy enigmas, but he had concealed the greatness even of himself, which he was with all his might revealing by his Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:9
verses.text: Now in what respect had the wise and prudent done wrong, that God should be hidden from them, when their wisdom and prudence had been insufficient to come to the knowledge of Him?  No way had been provided by himself, by any declaration of his works, or any vestiges whereby they might become wise and prudent.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:10
verses.text: However, if they had even failed in any duty towards a god whom they knew not, suppose him now at last to be known still they ought not to have found a jealous god in him who is introduced as unlike the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:11
verses.text: Therefore, since he had neither provided any materials in which he could have hidden anything, nor had any offenders from whom he could have hidden himself: since, again, even if he had had any, he ought not to have hidden himself from them, he will not now be himself the revealer, who was not previously the concealer; so neither will any be the Lord of heaven nor the Father of Christ but He in whom all these attributes consistently meet.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:12
verses.text: For He conceals by His preparatory apparatus of prophetic obscurity, the understanding of which is open to faith (for "if ye will not believe, ye shall not understand"); and He had offenders in those wise and prudent ones who would not seek after God, although He was to be discovered in His so many and mighty works, or who rashly philosophized about Him, and thereby furnished to heretics their arts; and lastly, He is a jealous God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:13
verses.text: Accordingly, that which Christ thanks God for doing, He long ago announced by Isaiah: "I will destroy the wisdom of the wise, and the understanding of the prudent will I hide".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:14
verses.text: So in another passage He intimates both that He has concealed, and that He will also reveal:  "I will give unto them treasures that have been hidden, and secret ones will I discover to them".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:15
verses.text: And again:  "Who else shall scatter the tokens of ventriloquists, and the devices of those who divine out of their own heart; turning wise men backward, and making their counsels foolish?" Now, if He has designated His Christ as an enlightener of the Gentiles, saying, "I have set thee for a light of the Gentiles;" and if we understand these to be meant in the word babes—as having been once dwarfs in knowledge and infants in prudence, and even now also babes in their lowliness of faith—we shall of course more easily understand how He who had once hidden "these things," and promised a revelation of them through Christ, was the same God as He who had now revealed them unto babes.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:16
verses.text: Else, if it was Marcion's god who revealed the things which had been formerly hidden by the Creator, it follows that he did the Creator's work by setting forth His deeds.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:17
verses.text: But he did it, say you, for His destruction, that he might refute them.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:18
verses.text: Therefore he ought to have refuted them to those from whom the Creator had hidden them, even the wise and prudent.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:19
verses.text: For if he had a kind intention in what he did, the gift of knowledge was due to those from whom the Creator had detained it, instead of the babes, to whom the Creator had grudged no gift.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:20
verses.text: But after all, it is, I presume, the edification rather than the demolition of the law and the prophets which we have thus far found effected in Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:21
verses.text: "All things," He says, "are delivered unto me of my Father".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:22
verses.text: You may believe Him, if He is the Christ of the Creator to whom all things belong; because the Creator has not delivered to a Son who is less than Himself all things, which He created by Him, that is to say, by His Word.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:23
verses.text: If, on the contrary, he is the notorious stranger, what are the "all things" which have been delivered to him by the Father? Are they the Creator's? Then the things which the Father delivered to the Son are good, and the Creator is therefore good, since all His "things" are good; whereas he is no longer good who has invaded another's good (domains) to deliver it to his son, thus teaching robbery of another's goods.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:24
verses.text: Surely he must be a most mendacious being, who had no other means of enriching his son than by helping himself to another's property!  Or else, if nothing of the Creator's has been delivered to him by the Father, by what right does he claim for himself (authority over) man?  Or again, if man has been delivered to him, and man alone, then man is not "all things".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:25
verses.text: But Scripture clearly says that a transfer of all things has been made to the Son.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:26
verses.text: If, however, you should interpret this "all" of the whole human race, that is, all nations, then the delivery of even these to the Son is within the purpose of the Creator: "I will give Thee the heathen for Thine inheritance, and the uttermost parts of the earth for Thy possession".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:27
verses.text: If, indeed, he has some things of his own, the whole of which he might give to his son, along with the man of the Creator, then show some one thing of them all, as a sample, that I may believe; lest I should have as much reason not to believe that all things belong to him, of whom I see nothing, as I have ground for believing that even the things which I see not are His, to whom belongs the universe, which I see.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:28
verses.text: But "no man knoweth who the Father is, but the Son; and who the Son is, but the Father, and he to whom the Son will reveal Him".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:29
verses.text: And so it was an unknown god that Christ preached! And other heretics, too, prop themselves up by this passage; alleging in opposition to it that the Creator was known to all, both to Israel by familiar intercourse, and to the Gentiles by nature.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:30
verses.text: Well, how is it He Himself testifies that He was not known to Israel?  "But Israel doth not know me, and my people doth not consider me;" nor to the Gentiles: "For, behold," says He, "of the nations I have no man".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:31
verses.text: Therefore He reckoned them "as the drop of a bucket," while "Sion He left as a look-out in a vineyard".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:32
verses.text: See, then, whether there be not here a confirmation of the prophet's word, when he rebukes that ignorance of man toward God which continued to the days of the Son of man.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:33
verses.text: For it was on this account that he inserted the clause that the Father is known by him to whom the Son has revealed Him, because it was even He who was announced as set by the Father to be a light to the Gentiles, who of course required to be enlightened concerning God, as well as to Israel, even by imparting to it a fuller knowledge of God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:34
verses.text: Arguments, therefore, will be of no use for belief in the rival god which may be suitable for the Creator, because it is only such as are unfit for the Creator which will be able to advance belief in His rival.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:35
verses.text: If you look also into the next words, "Blessed are the eyes which see the things which ye see, for I tell you that prophets have not seen the things which ye see," you will find that they follow from the sense above, that no man indeed had come to the knowledge of God as he ought to have done, since even the prophets had not seen the things which were being seen under Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:36
verses.text: Now if He had not been my Christ, He would not have made any mention of the prophets in this passage.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:37
verses.text: For what was there to wonder at, if they had not seen the things of a god who had been unknown to them, and was only revealed a long time after them? What blessedness, however, could theirs have been, who were then seeing what others were naturally unable to see, since it was of things which they had never predicted that they had not obtained the sight; if it were not because they might justly have seen the things pertaining to their God, which they had even predicted, but which they at the same time had not seen? This, however, will be the blessedness of others, even of such as were seeing the things which others had only foretold.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:38
verses.text: We shall by and by show, nay, we have already shown, that in Christ those things were seen which had been foretold, but yet had been hidden from the very prophets who foretold them, in order that they might be hidden also from the wise and the prudent.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:39
verses.text: In the true Gospel, a certain doctor of the law comes to the Lord and asks, "What shall I do to inherit eternal life?" In the heretical gospel life only is mentioned, without the attribute eternal; so that the lawyer seems to have consulted Christ simply about the life which the Creator in the law promises to prolong, and the Lord to have therefore answered him according to the law, "Thou shalt love the Lord thy God with all thy heart, and with all thy soul, and with all thy strength," since the question was concerning the conditions of mere life.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:40
verses.text: But the lawyer of course knew very well in what way the life which the law meant was to be obtained, so that his question could have had no relation to the life whose rules he was himself in the habit of teaching.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:41
verses.text: But seeing that even the dead were now raised by Christ, and being himself excited to the hope of an eternal life by these examples of a restored one, he would lose no more time in merely looking on (at the wonderful things which had made him) so high in hope.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:42
verses.text: He therefore consulted him about the attainment of eternal life.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:43
verses.text: Accordingly, the Lord, being Himself the same, and introducing no new precept other than that which relates above all others to (man's) entire salvation, even including the present and the future life, places before him the very essence of the law—that he should in every possible way love the Lord his God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:44
verses.text: If, indeed, it were only about a lengthened life, such as is at the Creator's disposal, that he inquired and Christ answered, and not about the eternal life, which is at the disposal of Marcion's god, how is he to obtain the eternal one?  Surely not in the same manner as the prolonged life.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:45
verses.text: For in proportion to the difference of the reward must be supposed to be also the diversity of the services.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:46
verses.text: Therefore your disciple, Marcion, will not obtain his eternal life in consequence of loving your God, in the same way as the man who loves the Creator will secure the lengthened life.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:47
verses.text: But how happens it that, if He is to be loved who promises the prolonged life, He is not much more to be loved who offers the eternal life? Therefore both one and the other life will be at the disposal of one and the same Lord; because one and the same discipline is to be followed for one and the other life.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:48
verses.text: What the Creator teaches to be loved, that must He necessarily maintain also by Christ, for that rule holds good here, which prescribes that greater things ought to be believed of Him who has first lesser proofs to show, than of him for whom no preceding smaller presumptions have secured a claim to be believed in things of higher import.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:49
verses.text: It matters not then, whether the word eternal has been interpolated by us.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:50
verses.text: It is enough for me, that the Christ who invited men to the eternal—not the lengthened—life, when consulted about the temporal life which he was destroying, did not choose to exhort the man rather to that eternal life which he was introducing.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 25:51
verses.text: Pray, what would the Creator's Christ have done, if He who had made man for loving the Creator did not belong to the Creator? I suppose He would have said that the Creator was not to be loved!.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:1
verses.text: From St.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:2
verses.text: Luke's Eleventh Chapter Other Evidence that Christ Comes from the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:3
verses.text: The Lord's Prayer and Other Words of Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:4
verses.text: The Dumb Spirit and Christ's Discourse on Occasion of the Expulsion.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:5
verses.text: The Exclamation of the Woman in the Crowd.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:6
verses.text: When in a certain place he had been praying to that Father above, looking up with insolent and audacious eyes to the heaven of the Creator, by whom in His rough and cruel nature he might have been crushed with hail and lightning—just as it was by Him contrived that he was (afterwards) attached to a cross at Jerusalem—one of his disciples came to him and said, "Master, teach us to pray, as John also taught his disciples".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:7
verses.text: This he said, forsooth, because he thought that different prayers were required for different gods! Now, he who had advanced such a conjecture as this should first show that another god had been proclaimed by Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:8
verses.text: For nobody would have wanted to know how to pray, before he had learned whom he was to pray to.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:9
verses.text: If, however, he had already learned this, prove it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:10
verses.text: If you find nowhere any proof, let me tell you that it was to the Creator that he asked for instruction in prayer, to whom John's disciples also used to pray.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:11
verses.text: But, inasmuch as John had introduced some new order of prayer, this disciple had not improperly presumed to think that he ought also to ask of Christ whether they too must not (according to some special rule of their Master) pray, not indeed to another god, but in another manner.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:12
verses.text: Christ accordingly would not have taught His disciple prayer before He had given him the knowledge of God Himself.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:13
verses.text: Therefore what He actually taught was prayer to Him whom the disciple had already known.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:14
verses.text: In short, you may discover in the import of the prayer what God is addressed therein.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:15
verses.text: To whom can I say, "Father?" To him who had nothing to do with making me, from whom I do not derive my origin? Or to Him, who, by making and fashioning me, became my parent? Of whom can I ask for His Holy Spirit? Of him who gives not even the mundane spirit; or of Him "who maketh His angels spirits," and whose Spirit it was which in the beginning hovered upon the waters.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:16
verses.text: Whose kingdom shall I wish to come—his, of whom I never heard as the king of glory; or His, in whose hand are even the hearts of kings? Who shall give me my daily bread? Shall it be he who produces for me not a grain of millet-seed; or He who even from heaven gave to His people day by day the bread of angels? Who shall forgive me my trespasses? He who, by refusing to judge them, does not retain them; or He who, unless He forgives them, will retain them, even to His judgment? Who shall suffer us not to be led into temptation? He before whom the tempter will never be able to tremble; or He who from the beginning has beforehand condemned the angel tempter? If any one, with such a form, invokes another god and not the Creator, he does not pray; he only blasphemes.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:17
verses.text: In like manner, from whom must I ask that I may receive? Of whom seek, that I may find? To whom knock, that it may be opened to me? Who has to give to him that asks, but He to whom all things belong, and whose am I also that am the asker? What, however, have I lost before that other god, that I should seek of him and find it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:18
verses.text: If it be wisdom and prudence, it is the Creator who has hidden them.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:19
verses.text: Shall I resort to him, then, in quest of them? If it be health and life, they are at the disposal of the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:20
verses.text: Nor must anything be sought and found anywhere else than there, where it is kept in secret that it may come to light.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:21
verses.text: So, again, at no other door will I knock than at that out of which my privilege has reached me.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:22
verses.text: In fine, if to receive, and to find, and to be admitted, is the fruit of labour and earnestness to him who has asked, and sought, and knocked, understand that these duties have been enjoined, and results promised, by the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:23
verses.text: As for that most excellent god of yours, coming as he professes gratuitously to help man, who was not his (creature), he could not have imposed upon him any labour, or (endowed him with) any earnestness.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:24
verses.text: For he would by this time cease to be the most excellent god, were he not spontaneously to give to every one who does not ask, and permit every one who seeks not to find, and open to every one who does not knock.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:25
verses.text: The Creator, on the contrary, was able to proclaim these duties and rewards by Christ, in order that man, who by sinning had offended his God, might toil on (in his probation), and by his perseverance in asking might receive, and in seeking might find, and in knocking might enter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:26
verses.text: Accordingly, the preceding similitude represents the man who went at night and begged for the loaves, in the light of a friend and not a stranger, and makes him knock at a friend's house and not at a stranger's.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:27
verses.text: But even if he has offended, man is more of a friend with the Creator than with the god of Marcion.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:28
verses.text: At His door, therefore, does he knock to whom he had the right of access; whose gate he had found; whom he knew to possess bread; in bed now with His children, whom He had willed to be born.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:29
verses.text: Even though the knocking is late in the day, it is yet the Creator's time.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:30
verses.text: To Him belongs the latest hour who owns an entire age and the end thereof.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:31
verses.text: As for the new god, however, no one could have knocked at his door late, for he has hardly yet seen the light of morning.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:32
verses.text: It is the Creator, who once shut the door to the Gentiles, which was then knocked at by the Jews, that both rises and gives, if not now to man as a friend, yet not as a stranger, but, as He says, "because of his importunity".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:33
verses.text: Importunate, however, the recent god could not have permitted any one to be in the short time (since his appearance).

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:34
verses.text: Him, therefore, whom you call the Creator recognise also as "Father".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:35
verses.text: It is even He who knows what His children require.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:36
verses.text: For when they asked for bread, He gave them manna from heaven; and when they wanted flesh, He sent them abundance of quails—not a serpent for a fish, nor for an egg a scorpion.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:37
verses.text: It will, however, appertain to Him not to give evil instead of good, who has both one and the other in His power.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:38
verses.text: Marcion's god, on the contrary, not having a scorpion, was unable to refuse to give what he did not possess; only He (could do so), who, having a scorpion, yet gives it not.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:39
verses.text: In like manner, it is He who will give the Holy Spirit, at whose command is also the unholy spirit.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:40
verses.text: When He cast out the "demon which was dumb" (and by a cure of this sort verified Isaiah), and having been charged with casting out demons by Beelzebub, He said, "If I by Beelzebub cast out demons, by whom do your sons cast them out?" By such a question what does He otherwise mean, than that He ejects the spirits by the same power by which their sons also did—that is, by the power of the Creator?  For if you suppose the meaning to be, "If I by Beelzebub, etc.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:41
verses.text: , by whom your sons?"—as if He would reproach them with having the power of Beelzebub,—you are met at once by the preceding sentence, that "Satan cannot be divided against himself".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:42
verses.text: So that it was not by Beelzebub that even they were casting out demons, but (as we have said) by the power of the Creator; and that He might make this understood, He adds: "But if I with the finger of God cast out demons, is not the kingdom of God come near unto you?" For the magicians who stood before Pharaoh and resisted Moses called the power of the Creator "the finger of God".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:43
verses.text: It was the finger of God, because it was a sign that even a thing of weakness was yet abundant in strength.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:44
verses.text: This Christ also showed, when, recalling to notice (and not obliterating) those ancient wonders which were really His own, He said that the power of God must be understood to be the finger of none other God than Him, under whom it had received this appellation.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:45
verses.text: His kingdom, therefore, was come near to them, whose power was called His "finger".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:46
verses.text: Well, therefore, did He connect with the parable of "the strong man armed," whom "a stronger man still overcame," the prince of the demons, whom He had already called Beelzebub and Satan; signifying that it was he who was overcome by the finger of God, and not that the Creator had been subdued by another god.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:47
verses.text: Besides, how could His kingdom be still standing, with its boundaries, and laws, and functions, whom, even if the whole world were left entire to Him, Marcion's god could possibly seem to have overcome as "the stronger than He," if it were not in consequence of His law that even Marcionites were constantly dying, by returning in their dissolution to the ground, and were so often admonished by even a scorpion, that the Creator had by no means been overcome? "A (certain) mother of the company exclaims, 'Blessed is the womb that bare Thee, and the paps which Thou hast sucked;' but the Lord said, 'Yea, rather, blessed are they that hear the word of God, and keep it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:48
verses.text: '" Now He had in precisely similar terms rejected His mother or His brethren, whilst preferring those who heard and obeyed God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:49
verses.text: His mother, however, was not here present with Him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:50
verses.text: On that former occasion, therefore, He had not denied that He was her son by birth.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 26:51
verses.text: On hearing this (salutation) the second time, He the second time transferred, as He had done before, the "blessedness" to His disciples from the womb and the paps of His mother, from whom, however, unless He had in her (a real mother) He could not have transferred it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 27:1
verses.text: Christ's Reprehension of the Pharisees Seeking a Sign.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 27:2
verses.text: His Censure of Their Love of Outward Show Rather Than Inward Holiness.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 27:3
verses.text: Scripture Abounds with Admonitions of a Similar Purport.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 27:4
verses.text: Proofs of His Mission from the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 27:5
verses.text: I prefer elsewhere refuting the faults which the Marcionites find in the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 27:6
verses.text: It is here enough that they are also found in Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 27:7
verses.text: Behold how unequal, inconsistent, and capricious he is! Teaching one thing and doing another, he enjoins "giving to every one that seeks;" and yet he himself refuses to give to those "who seek a sign".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 27:8
verses.text: For a vast age he hides his own light from men, and yet says that a candle must not be hidden, but affirms that it ought to be set upon a candlestick, that it may give light to all.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 27:9
verses.text: He forbids cursing again, and cursing much more of course; and yet he heaps his woe upon the Pharisees and doctors of the law.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 27:10
verses.text: Who so closely resembles my God as His own Christ? We have often already laid it down for certain, that He could not have been branded as the destroyer of the law if He had promulged another god.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 27:11
verses.text: Therefore even the Pharisee, who invited Him to dinner in the passage before us, expressed some surprise in His presence that He had not washed before He sat down to meat, in accordance with the law, since it was the God of the law that He was proclaiming.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 27:12
verses.text: Jesus also interpreted the law to him when He told him that they "made clean the outside of the cup and the platter, whereas their inward part was full of ravening and wickedness".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 27:13
verses.text: This He said, to signify that by the cleansing of vessels was to be understood before God the purification of men, inasmuch as it was about a man, and not about an unwashed vessel, that even this Pharisee had been treating in His presence.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 27:14
verses.text: He therefore said: "You wash the outside of the cup," that is, the flesh, "but you do not cleanse your inside part," that is, the soul; adding: "Did not He that made the outside," that is, the flesh, "also make the inward part," that is to say, the soul?—by which assertion He expressly declared that to the same God belongs the cleansing of a man's external and internal nature, both alike being in the power of Him who prefers mercy not only to man's washing, but even to sacrifice.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 27:15
verses.text: For He subjoins the command: "Give what ye possess as alms, and all things shall be clean unto you".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 27:16
verses.text: Even if another god could have enjoined mercy, he could not have done so previous to his becoming known.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 27:17
verses.text: Furthermore, it is in this passage evident that they were not reproved concerning their God, but concerning a point of His instruction to them, when He prescribed to them figuratively the cleansing of their vessels, but really the works of merciful dispositions.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 27:18
verses.text: In like manner, He upbraids them for tithing paltry herbs, but at the same time "passing over hospitality and the love of God".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 27:19
verses.text: The vocation and the love of what God, but Him by whose law of tithes they used to offer their rue and mint? For the whole point of the rebuke lay in this, that they cared about small matters in His service of course, to whom they failed to exhibit their weightier duties when He commanded them: "Thou shalt love with all thine heart, and with all thy soul, and with all thy strength, the Lord thy God, who hath called thee out of Egypt".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 27:20
verses.text: Besides, time enough had not yet passed to admit of Christ's requiring so premature—nay, as yet so distasteful—a love towards a new and recent, not to say a hardly yet developed, deity.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 27:21
verses.text: When, again, He upbraids those who caught at the uppermost places and the honour of public salutations, He only follows out the Creator's course, who calls ambitious persons of this character "rulers of Sodom," who forbids us "to put confidence even in princes," and pronounces him to be altogether wretched who places his confidence in man.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 27:22
verses.text: But whoever aims at high position, because he would glory in the officious attentions of other people, (in every such case,) inasmuch as He forbade such attentions (in the shape) of placing hope and confidence in man, He at the same time censured all who were ambitious of high positions.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 27:23
verses.text: He also inveighs against the doctors of the law themselves, because they were "lading men with burdens grievous to be borne, which they did not venture to touch with even a finger of their own;" but not as if He made a mock of the burdens of the law with any feeling of detestation towards it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 27:24
verses.text: For how could He have felt aversion to the law, who used with so much earnestness to upbraid them for passing over its weightier matters, alms—giving, hospitality, and the love of God? Nor, indeed, was it only these great things (which He recognized), but even the tithes of rue and the cleansing of cups.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 27:25
verses.text: But, in truth, He would rather have deemed them excusable for being unable to carry burdens which could not be borne.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 27:26
verses.text: What, then, are the burdens which He censures? None but those which they were accumulating of their own accord, when they taught for commandments the doctrines of men; for the sake of private advantage joining house to house, so as to deprive their neighbour of his own; cajoling the people, loving gifts, pursuing rewards, robbing the poor of the rights of judgment, that they might have the widow for a prey and the fatherless for a spoil.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 27:27
verses.text: Of these Isaiah also says, "Woe unto them that are strong in Jerusalem!" and again, "They that demand you shall rule over you".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 27:28
verses.text: And who did this more than the lawyers? Now, if these offended Christ, it was as belonging to Him that they offended Him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 27:29
verses.text: He would have aimed no blow at the teachers of an alien law.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 27:30
verses.text: But why is a "woe" pronounced against them for "building the sepulchres of the prophets whom their fathers had killed?" They rather deserved praise, because by such an act of piety they seemed to show that they did not allow the deeds of their fathers.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 27:31
verses.text: Was it not because (Christ) was jealous of such a disposition as the Marcionites denounce, visiting the sins of the fathers upon the children unto the fourth generation? What "key," indeed, was it which these lawyers had, but the interpretation of the law? Into the perception of this they neither entered themselves, even because they did not believe (for "unless ye believe, ye shall not understand"); nor did they permit others to enter, because they preferred to teach them for commandments even the doctrines of men.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 27:32
verses.text: When, therefore, He reproached those who did not themselves enter in, and also shut the door against others, must He be regarded as a disparager of the law, or as a supporter of it? If a disparager, those who were hindering the law ought to have been pleased; if a supporter, He is no longer an enemy of the law.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 27:33
verses.text: But all these imprecations He uttered in order to tarnish the Creator as a cruel Being, against whom such as offended were destined to have a "woe".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 27:34
verses.text: And who would not rather have feared to provoke a cruel Being, by withdrawing allegiance from Him? Therefore the more He represented the Creator to be an object of fear, the more earnestly would He teach that He ought to be served.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 27:35
verses.text: Thus would it behove the Creator's Christ to act.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 28:1
verses.text: Examples from the Old Testament, Balaam, Moses, and Hezekiah, to Show How Completely the Instruction and Conduct of Christ Are in Keeping with the Will and Purpose of the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 28:2
verses.text: Justly, therefore, was the hypocrisy of the Pharisees displeasing to Him, loving God as they did with their lips, but not with their heart.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 28:3
verses.text: "Beware," He says to the disciples, "of the leaven of the Pharisees, which is hypocrisy," not the proclamation of the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 28:4
verses.text: The Son hates those who refused obedience to the Father; nor does He wish His disciples to show such a disposition towards Him—not (let it be observed) towards another god, against whom such hypocrisy indeed might have been admissible, as that which He wished to guard His disciples against.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 28:5
verses.text: It is the example of the Pharisees which He forbids.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 28:6
verses.text: It was in respect of Him against whom the Pharisees were sinning that (Christ) now forbade His disciples to offend.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 28:7
verses.text: Since, then, He had censured their hypocrisy, which covered the secrets of the heart, and obscured with superficial offices the mysteries of unbelief, because (while holding the key of knowledge) it would neither enter in itself, nor permit others to enter in, He therefore adds, "There is nothing covered that shall not be revealed; neither hid, which shall not be known," in order that no one should suppose that He was attempting the revelation and the recognition of an hitherto unknown and hidden god.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 28:8
verses.text: When He remarks also on their murmurs and taunts, in saying of Him, "This man casteth out devils only through Beelzebub," He means that all these imputations would come forth to the light of day, and be in the mouths of men in consequence of the promulgation of the Gospel.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 28:9
verses.text: He then turns to His disciples with these words, "I say unto you, my friends, Be not afraid of them which can only kill the body, and after that have no more power over you".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 28:10
verses.text: They will, however, find Isaiah had already said, "See how the just man is taken away, and no man layeth it to heart".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 28:11
verses.text: "But I will show you whom ye shall fear: fear Him who, after He hath killed, hath power to cast into hell" (meaning, of course, the Creator); "yea, I say unto you, fear Him".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 28:12
verses.text: Now, it would here be enough for my purpose that He forbids offence being given to Him whom He orders to be feared; and that He orders Him to be respected whom He forbids to be offended; and that He who gives these commands belongs to that very God for whom He procures this fear, this absence of offence, and this respect.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 28:13
verses.text: But this conclusion I can draw also from the following words: "For I say unto you, Whosoever shall confess me before men, him will I also confess before God".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 28:14
verses.text: Now they who shall confess Christ will have to be slain before men, but they will have nothing more to suffer after they have been put to death by them.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 28:15
verses.text: These therefore will be they whom He forewarns above not to be afraid of being only killed; and this forewarning He offers, in order that He might subjoin a clause on the necessity of confessing Him: "Every one that denieth me before men shall be denied before God"—by Him, of course, who would have confessed him, if he had only confessed God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 28:16
verses.text: Now, He who will confess the confessor is the very same God who will also deny the denier of Himself.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 28:17
verses.text: Again, if it is the confessor who will have nothing to fear after his violent death, it is the denier to whom everything will become fearful after his natural death.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 28:18
verses.text: Since, therefore, that which will have to be feared after death, even the punishment of hell, belongs to the Creator, the denier, too, belongs to the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 28:19
verses.text: As with the denier, however, so with the confessor: if he should deny God, he will plainly have to suffer from God, although from men he had nothing more to suffer after they had put him to death.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 28:20
verses.text: And so Christ is the Creator's, because He shows that all those who deny Him ought to fear the Creator's hell.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 28:21
verses.text: After deterring His disciples from denial of Himself, He adds an admonition to fear blasphemy: "Whosoever shall speak against the Son of man, it shall be forgiven him; but whosoever shall speak against the Holy Ghost, it shall not be forgiven him".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 28:22
verses.text: Now, if both the remission and the retention of sin savour of a judicial God, the Holy Ghost, who is not to be blasphemed, will belong to Him, who will not forgive the blasphemy; just as He who, in the preceding passage, was not to be denied, belonged to, Him who would, after He had killed, also cast into hell.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 28:23
verses.text: Now, since it is Christ who averts blasphemy from the Creator, I am at a loss to know in what manner His adversary could have come.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 28:24
verses.text: Else, if by these sayings He throws a black cloud of censure over the severity of Him who will not forgive blasphemy and will kill even to hell, it follows that the very spirit of that rival god may be blasphemed with impunity, and his Christ denied; and that there is no difference, in fact, between worshipping and despising him; but that, as there is no punishment for the contempt, so there is no reward for the worship, which men need expect.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 28:25
verses.text: When "brought before magistrates," and examined, He forbids them "to take thought how they shall answer;" "for," says He, "the Holy Ghost shall teach you in that very hour what ye ought to say".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 28:26
verses.text: If such an injunction as this comes from the Creator, the precept will only be His by whom an example was previously given.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 28:27
verses.text: The prophet Balaam, in Numbers, when sent forth by king Balak to curse Israel, with whom he was commencing war, was at the same moment filled with the Spirit.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 28:28
verses.text: Instead of the curse which he was come to pronounce, he uttered the blessing which the Spirit at that very hour inspired him with; having previously declared to the king's messengers, and then to the king himself, that he could only speak forth that which God should put into his mouth.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 28:29
verses.text: The novel doctrines of the new Christ are such as the Creator's servants initiated long before! But see how clear a difference there is between the example of Moses and of Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 28:30
verses.text: Moses voluntarily interferes with brothers who were quarrelling, and chides the offender:  "Wherefore smitest thou thy fellow?"  He is, however, rejected by him:  "Who made thee a prince or a judge over us?" Christ, on the contrary, when requested by a certain man to compose a strife between him and his brother about dividing an inheritance, refused His assistance, although in so honest a cause.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 28:31
verses.text: Well, then, my Moses is better than your Christ, aiming as he did at the peace of brethren, and obviating their wrong.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 28:32
verses.text: But of course the case must be different with Christ, for he is the Christ of the simply good and non-judicial god.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 28:33
verses.text: "Who," says he, "made me a judge over you?" No other word of excuse was he able to find, without using that with which the wicked, man and impious brother had rejected the defender of probity and piety! In short, he approved of the excuse, although a bad one, by his use of it; and of the act, although a bad one, by his refusal to make peace between brothers.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 28:34
verses.text: Or rather, would He not show His resentment at the rejection of Moses with such a word?  And therefore did He not wish in a similar case of contentious brothers, to confound them with the recollection of so harsh a word? Clearly so.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 28:35
verses.text: For He had Himself been present in Moses, who heard such a rejection—even He, the Spirit of the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 28:36
verses.text: I think that we have already, in another passage, sufficiently shown that the glory of riches is condemned by our God, "who putteth down the mighty from their throne, and exalts the poor from the dunghill".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 28:37
verses.text: From Him, therefore, will proceed the parable of the rich man, who flattered himself about the increase of his fields, and to Whom God said: "Thou fool, this night shall they require thy soul of thee; then whose shall those things be which thou hast provided?" It was just in the like manner that the king Hezekiah heard from Isaiah the sad doom of his kingdom, when he gloried, before the envoys of Babylon, in his treasures and the deposits of his precious things.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:1
verses.text: Parallels from the Prophets to Illustrate Christ's Teaching in the Rest of This Chapter of St.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:2
verses.text: Luke.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:3
verses.text: The Sterner Attributes of Christ, in His Judicial Capacity, Show Him to Have Come from the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:4
verses.text: Incidental Rebukes of Marcion's Doctrine of Celibacy, and of His Altering of the Text of the Gospel.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:5
verses.text: Who would be unwilling that we should distress ourselves about sustenance for our life, or clothing for our body, but He who has provided these things already for man; and who, therefore, while distributing them to us, prohibits all anxiety respecting them as an outrage against his liberality?—who has adapted the nature of "life" itself to a condition "better than meat," and has fashioned the material of "the body," so as to make it "more than raiment;" whose "ravens, too, neither sow nor reap, nor gather into storehouses, and are yet fed" by Himself; whose "lilies and grass also toil not, nor spin, and yet are clothed" by Him; whose "Solomon, moreover, was transcendent in glory, and yet was not arrayed like" the humble flower.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:6
verses.text: Besides, nothing can be more abrupt than that one God should be distributing His bounty, while the other should bid us take no thought about (so kindly a) distribution—and that, too, with the intention of derogating (from his liberality).

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:7
verses.text: Whether, indeed, it is as depreciating the Creator that he does not wish such trifles to be thought of, concerning which neither the crows nor the lilies labour, because, forsooth, they come spontaneously to hand by reason of their very worthlessness, will appear a little further on.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:8
verses.text: Meanwhile, how is it that He chides them as being "of little faith?" What faith?  Does He mean that faith which they were as yet unable to manifest perfectly in a god who has hardly yet revealed, and whom they were in process of learning as well as they could; or that faith which they for this express reason owed to the Creator, because they believed that He was of His own will supplying these wants of the human race, and therefore took no thought about them?  Now, when He adds, "For all these things do the nations of the world seek after," even by their not believing in God as the Creator and Giver of all things, since He was unwilling that they should be like these nations, He therefore upbraided them as being defective of faith in the same God, in whom He remarked that the Gentiles were quite wanting in faith.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:9
verses.text: When He further adds, "But your Father knoweth that ye have need of these things," I would first ask, what Father Christ would have to be here understood? If He points to their own Creator, He also affirms Him to be good, who knows what His children have need of; but if He refers to that other god, how does he know that food and raiment are necessary to man, seeing that he has made no such provision for him? For if he had known the want, he would have made the provision.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:10
verses.text: If, however, he knows what things man has need of, and yet has failed to supply them, he is in the failure guilty of either malignity or weakness.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:11
verses.text: But when he confessed that these things are necessary to man, he really affirmed that they are good.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:12
verses.text: For nothing that is evil is necessary.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:13
verses.text: So that he will not be any longer a depreciator of the works and the indulgences of the Creator, that I may here complete the answer which I deferred giving above.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:14
verses.text: Again, if it is another god who has foreseen man's wants, and is supplying them, how is it that Marcion's Christ himself promises them? Is he liberal with another's property? "Seek ye," says he, "the kingdom of God, and all these things shall be added unto you"—by himself, of course.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:15
verses.text: But if by himself, what sort of being is he, who shall bestow the things of another?  If by the Creator, whose all things are, then who is he that promises what belongs to another?  If these things are "additions" to the kingdom, they must be placed in the second rank; and the second rank belongs to Him to whom the first also does; His are the food and raiment, whose is the kingdom.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:16
verses.text: Thus to the Creator belongs the entire promise, the full reality of its parables, the perfect equalization of its similitudes; for these have respect to none other than Him to whom they have a parity of relation in every point.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:17
verses.text: We are servants because we have a Lord in our God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:18
verses.text: We ought "to have our loins girded:" in other words, we are to be free from the embarrassments of a perplexed and much occupied life; "to have our lights burning," that is, our minds kindled by faith, and resplendent with the works of truth.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:19
verses.text: And thus "to wait for our Lord," that is, Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:20
verses.text: Whence "returning?" If "from the wedding," He is the Christ of the Creator, for the wedding is His.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:21
verses.text: If He is not the Creator's, not even Marcion himself would have gone to the wedding, although invited, for in his god he discovers one who hates the nuptial bed.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:22
verses.text: The parable would therefore have failed in the person of the Lord, if He were not a Being to whom a wedding is consistent.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:23
verses.text: In the next parable also he makes a flagrant mistake, when he assigns to the person of the Creator that "thief, whose hour, if the father of the family had only known, he would not have suffered his house to be broken through".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:24
verses.text: How can the Creator wear in any way the aspect of a thief, Lord as He is of all mankind? No one pilfers or plunders his own property, but he rather acts the part of one who swoops down on the things of another, and alienates man from his Lord.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:25
verses.text: Again, when He indicates to us that the devil is "the thief," whose hour at the very beginning of the world, if man had known, he would never have been broken in upon by him, He warns us "to be ready," for this reason, because "we know not the hour when the Son of man shall come"—not as if He were Himself the thief, but rather as being the judge of those who prepared not themselves, and used no precaution against the thief.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:26
verses.text: Since, then, He is the Son of man, I hold Him to be the Judge, and in the Judge I claim the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:27
verses.text: If then in this passage he displays the Creator's Christ under the title "Son of man," that he may give us some presage of the thief, of the period of whose coming we are ignorant, you still have it ruled above, that no one is the thief of his own property; besides which, there is our principle also unimpaired—that in as far as He insists on the Creator as an object of fear, in so far does He belong to the Creator, and does the Creator's work.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:28
verses.text: When, therefore, Peter asked whether He had spoken the parable "unto them, or even to all," He sets forth for them, and for all who should bear rule in the churches, the similitude of stewards.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:29
verses.text: That steward who should treat his fellow-servants well in his Lord's absence, would on his return be set as ruler over all his property; but he who should act otherwise should be severed, and have his portion with the unbelievers, when his lord should return on the day when he looked not for him, at the hour when he was not aware—even that Son of man, the Creator's Christ, not a thief, but a Judge.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:30
verses.text: He accordingly, in this passage, either presents to us the Lord as a Judge, and instructs us in His character, or else as the simply good god; if the latter, he now also affirms his judicial attribute, although the heretic refuses to admit it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:31
verses.text: For an attempt is made to modify this sense when it is applied to his god,—as if it were an act of serenity and mildness simply to sever the man off, and to assign him a portion with the unbelievers, under the idea that he was not summoned (before the judge), but only returned to his own state! As if this very process did not imply a judicial act!  What folly! What will be the end of the severed ones? Will it not be the forfeiture of salvation, since their separation will be from those who shall attain salvation? What, again, will be the condition of the unbelievers?  Will it not be damnation? Else, if these severed and unfaithful ones shall have nothing to suffer, there will, on the other hand, be nothing for the accepted and the believers to obtain.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:32
verses.text: If, however, the accepted and the believers shall attain salvation, it must needs be that the rejected and the unbelieving should incur the opposite issue, even the loss of salvation.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:33
verses.text: Now here is a judgment, and He who holds it out before us belongs to the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:34
verses.text: Whom else than the God of retribution can I understand by Him who shall "beat His servants with stripes," either "few or many," and shall exact from them what He had committed to them? Whom is it suitable for me to obey, but Him who remunerates?  Your Christ proclaims, "I am come to send fire on the earth".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:35
verses.text: That most lenient being, the lord who has no hell, not long before had restrained his disciples from demanding fire on the churlish village.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:36
verses.text: Whereas He burnt up Sodom and Gomorrah with a tempest of fire.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:37
verses.text: Of Him the psalmist sang, "A fire shall go out before Him, and burn up His enemies round about".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:38
verses.text: By Hoses He uttered the threat, "I will send a fire upon the cities of Judah;" and by Isaiah, "A fire has been kindled in mine anger".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:39
verses.text: He cannot lie.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:40
verses.text: If it is not He who uttered His voice out of even the burning bush, it can be of no importance what fire you insist upon being understood.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:41
verses.text: Even if it be but figurative fire, yet, from the very fact that he takes from my element illustrations for His own sense, He is mine, because He uses what is mine.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:42
verses.text: The similitude of fire must belong to Him who owns the reality thereof.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:43
verses.text: But He will Himself best explain the quality of that fire which He mentioned, when He goes on to say, "Suppose ye that I am come to give peace on earth? I tell you, Nay; but rather division".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:44
verses.text: It is written "a sword," but Marcion makes an emendation of the word, just as if a division were not the work of the sword.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:45
verses.text: He, therefore, who refused to give peace, intended also the fire of destruction.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:46
verses.text: As is the combat, so is the burning.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:47
verses.text: As is the sword, so is the flame.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:48
verses.text: Neither is suitable for its lord.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:49
verses.text: He says at last, "The father shall be divided against the son, and the son against the father; the mother against the daughter, and the daughter against the mother; the mother-in-law against the daughter-in-law, and the daughter-in-law against the mother-in-law".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:50
verses.text: Since this battle among the relatives was sung by the prophet's trumpet in the very words, I fear that Micah must have predicted it to Marcion's Christ!  On this account He pronounced them "hypocrites," because they could "discern the face of the sky and the earth, but could not distinguish this time," when of course He ought to have been recognised, fulfilling (as he was) all things which had been predicted concerning them, and teaching them so.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:51
verses.text: But then who could know the times of him of whom he had no evidence to prove his existence?  Justly also does He upbraid them for "not even of themselves judging what is right".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:52
verses.text: Of old does He command by Zechariah, "Execute the judgment of truth and peace;" by Jeremiah, "Execute judgment and righteousness;" by Isaiah, "Judge the fatherless, plead for the widow," charging it as a fault upon the vine of Sorech, that when "He looked for righteousness therefrom, there was only a cry" (of oppression).

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:53
verses.text: The same God who had taught them to act as He commanded them, was now requiring that they should act of their own accord.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:54
verses.text: He who had sown the precept, was now pressing to an abundant harvest from it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:55
verses.text: But how absurd, that he should now be commanding them to judge righteously, who was destroying God the righteous Judge! For the Judge, who commits to prison, and allows no release out of it without the payment of "the very last mite," they treat of in the person of the Creator, with the view of disparaging Him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:56
verses.text: Which cavil, however, I deem it necessary to meet with the same answer.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 29:57
verses.text: For as often as the Creator's severity is paraded before us, so often is Christ (shown to be) His, to whom He urges submission by the motive of fear.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 30:1
verses.text: Parables of the Mustard-Seed, and of the Leaven.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 30:2
verses.text: Transition to the Solemn Exclusion Which Will Ensue When the Master of the House Has Shut the Door.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 30:3
verses.text: This Judicial Exclusion Will Be Administered by Christ, Who is Shown Thereby to Possess the Attribute of the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 30:4
verses.text: When the question was again raised concerning a cure performed on the Sabbath-day, how did He discuss it: "Doth not each of you on the Sabbath loose his ass or his ox from the stall, and lead him away to watering?" When, therefore, He did a work according to the condition prescribed by the law, He affirmed, instead of breaking, the law, which commanded that no work should be done, except what might be done for any living being; and if for any one, then how much more for a human life? In the case of the parables, it is allowed that I everywhere require a congruity.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 30:5
verses.text: "The kingdom of God," says He, "is like a grain of mustard-seed which a man took and cast into his garden".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 30:6
verses.text: Who must be understood as meant by the man? Surely Christ, because (although Marcion's) he was called "the Son of man".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 30:7
verses.text: He received from the Father the seed of the kingdom, that is, the word of the gospel, and sowed it in his garden—in the world, of course—in man at the present day, for instance.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 30:8
verses.text: Now, whereas it is said, "in his garden," but neither the world nor man is his property, but the Creator's, therefore He who sowed seed in His own ground is shown to be the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 30:9
verses.text: Else, if, to evade this snare, they should choose to transfer the person of the man from Christ to any person who receives the seed of the kingdom and sows it in the garden of his own heart, not even this meaning would suit any other than the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 30:10
verses.text: For how happens it, if the kingdom belong to the most lenient god, that it is closely followed up by a fervent judgment, the severity of which brings weeping? With regard, indeed, to the following similitude, I have my fears lest it should somehow presage the kingdom of the rival god!  For He compared it, not to the unleavened bread which the Creator is more familiar with, but to leaven.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 30:11
verses.text: Now this is a capital conjecture for men who are begging for arguments.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 30:12
verses.text: I must, however, on my side, dispel one fond conceit by another, and contend with even leaven is suitable for the kingdom of the Creator, because after it comes the oven, or, if you please, the furnace of hell.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 30:13
verses.text: How often has He already displayed Himself as a Judge, and in the Judge the Creator? How often, indeed, has He repelled, and in the repulse condemned? In the present passage, for instance, He says, "When once the master of the house is risen up;" but in what sense except that in which Isaiah said, "When He ariseth to shake terribly the earth?" "And hath shut to the door," thereby shutting out the wicked, of course; and when these knock, He will answer, "I know you not whence ye are;" and when they recount how "they have eaten and drunk in His presence," He will further say to them, "Depart from me, all ye workers of iniquity; there shall be weeping and gnashing of teeth".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 30:14
verses.text: But where?  Outside, no doubt, when they shall have been excluded with the door shut on them by Him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 30:15
verses.text: There will therefore be punishment inflicted by Him who excludes for punishment, when they shall behold the righteous entering the kingdom of God, but themselves detained without.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 30:16
verses.text: By whom detained outside? If by the Creator, who shall be within receiving the righteous into the kingdom? The good God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 30:17
verses.text: What, therefore, is the Creator about, that He should detain outside for punishment those whom His adversary shut out, when He ought rather to have kindly received them, if they must come into His hands, for the greater irritation of His rival?  But when about to exclude the wicked, he must, of course, either be aware that the Creator would detain them for punishment, or not be aware.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 30:18
