verses.text: He thus honoured the blind man's faith which had acknowledged His Sonship to David; but at the same time He struck a blow at the tradition of the Scribes, which prevented them from knowing that He was also (David's) Lord.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 38:45
verses.text: Whatever had relation to the glory of the Creator's Christ, no other would thus guard and maintain but Himself the Creator's Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:1
verses.text: Concerning Those Who Come in the Name of Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:2
verses.text: The Terrible Signs of His Coming.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:3
verses.text: He Whose Coming is So Grandly Described Both in the Old Testament and the New Testament, is None Other Than the Christ of the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:4
verses.text: This Proof Enhanced by the Parable of the Fig-Tree and All the Trees.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:5
verses.text: Parallel Passages of Prophecy.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:6
verses.text: As touching the propriety of His names, it has already been seen that both of them are suitable to Him who was the first both to announce His Christ to mankind, and to give Him the further name of Jesus.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:7
verses.text: The impudence, therefore, of Marcion's Christ will be evident, when he says that many will come in his name, whereas this name does not at all belong to him, since he is not the Christ and Jesus of the Creator, to whom these names do properly appertain; and more especially when he prohibits those to be received whose very equal in imposture he is, inasmuch as he (equally with them) comes in a name which belongs to another—unless it was his business to warn off from a mendaciously assumed name the disciples (of One) who, by reason of His name being properly given to Him, possessed also the verity thereof.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:8
verses.text: But when "they shall by and by come and say, I am Christ," they will be received by you, who have already received one altogether like them.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:9
verses.text: Christ, however, comes in His own name.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:10
verses.text: What will you do, then, when He Himself comes who is the very Proprietor of these names, the Creator's Christ and Jesus? Will you reject Him? But how iniquitous, how unjust and disrespectful to the good God, that you should not receive Him who comes in His own name, when you have received another in His name! Now, let us see what are the signs which He ascribes to the times.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:11
verses.text: "Wars," I observe, "and kingdom against kingdom, and nation against nation, and pestilence, and famines, and earthquakes, and fearful sights, and great signs from heaven"—all which things are suitable for a severe and terrible God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:12
verses.text: Now, when He goes on to say that "all these things must needs come to pass," what does He represent Himself to be?  The Destroyer, or the Defender of the Creator? For He affirms that these appointments of His must fully come to pass; but surely as the good God, He would have frustrated rather than advanced events so sad and terrible, if they had not been His own (decrees).

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:13
verses.text: "But before all these," He foretells that persecutions and sufferings were to come upon them, which indeed were "to turn for a testimony to them," and for their salvation.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:14
verses.text: Hear what is predicted in Zechariah: "The Lord of hosts shall protect them; and they shall devour them, and subdue them with sling-stones; and they shall drink their blood like wine, and they shall fill the bowls as it were of the altar.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:15
verses.text: And the Lord shall save them in that day, even His people, like sheep; because as sacred stones they roll," etc.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:16
verses.text: And that you may not suppose that these predictions refer to such sufferings as await them from so many wars with strangers, consider the nature (of the sufferings).

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:17
verses.text: In a prophecy of wars which were to be waged with legitimate arms, no one would think of enumerating stones as weapons, which are better known in popular crowds and unarmed tumults.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:18
verses.text: Nobody measures the copious streams of blood which flow in war by bowlfuls, nor limits it to what is shed upon a single altar.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:19
verses.text: No one gives the name of sheep to those who fall in battle with arms in hand, and while repelling force with force, but only to those who are slain, yielding themselves up in their own place of duty and with patience, rather than fighting in self-defence.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:20
verses.text: In short, as he says, "they roll as sacred stones," and not like soldiers fight.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:21
verses.text: Stones are they, even foundation stones, upon which we are ourselves edified—"built," as St.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:22
verses.text: Paul says, "upon the foundation of the apostles," who, like "consecrated stones," were rolled up and down exposed to the attack of all men.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:23
verses.text: And therefore in this passage He forbids men "to meditate before what they answer" when brought before tribunals, even as once He suggested to Balaam the message which he had not thought of, nay, contrary to what he had thought; and promised "a mouth" to Moses, when he pleaded in excuse the slowness of his speech, and that wisdom which, by Isaiah, He showed to be irresistible: "One shall say, I am the Lord's, and shall call himself by the name of Jacob, and another shall subscribe himself by the name of Israel".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:24
verses.text: Now, what plea is wiser and more irresistible than the simple and open confession made in a martyr's cause, who "prevails with God"—which is what "Israel" means? Now, one cannot wonder that He forbade "premeditation," who actually Himself received from the Father the ability of uttering words in season: "The Lord hath given to me the tongue of the learned, that I should know how to speak a word in season (to him that is weary);" except that Marcion introduces to us a Christ who is not subject to the Father.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:25
verses.text: That persecutions from one's nearest friends are predicted, and calumny out of hatred to His name, I need not again refer to.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:26
verses.text: But "by patience," says He, "ye shall yourselves be saved".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:27
verses.text: Of this very patience the Psalm says, "The patient endurance of the just shall not perish for ever;" because it is said in another Psalm, "Precious (in the sight of the Lord) is the death of the just"—arising, no doubt, out of their patient endurance, so that Zechariah declares: "A crown shall be to them that endure".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:28
verses.text: But that you may not boldly contend that it was as announcers of another god that the apostles were persecuted by the Jews, remember that even the prophets suffered the same treatment of the Jews, and that they were not the heralds of any other god than the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:29
verses.text: Then, having shown what was to be the period of the destruction, even "when Jerusalem should begin to be compassed with armies," He described the signs of the end of all things: "portents in the sun, and the moon, and the stars, and upon the earth distress of nations in perplexity—like the sea roaring—by reason of their expectation of the evils which are coming on the earth".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:30
verses.text: That "the very powers also of heaven have to be shaken," you may find in Joel: "And I will show wonders in the heavens and in the earth—blood and fire, and pillars of smoke; the sun shall be turned into darkness, and the moon into blood, before the great and terrible day of the Lord come".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:31
verses.text: In Habakkuk also you have this statement: "With rivers shall the earth be cleaved; the nations shall see thee, and be in pangs.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:32
verses.text: Thou shalt disperse the waters with thy step; the deep uttered its voice; the height of its fear was raised; the sun and the moon stood still in their course; into light shall thy coruscations go; and thy shield shall be (like) the glittering of the lightning's flash; in thine anger thou shalt grind the earth, and shalt thresh the nations in thy wrath".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:33
verses.text: There is thus an agreement, I apprehend, between the sayings of the Lord and of the prophets touching the shaking of the earth, and the elements, and the nations thereof.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:34
verses.text: But what does the Lord say afterwards? "And then shall they see the Son of man coming from the heavens with very great power.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:35
verses.text: And when these things shall come to pass, ye shall look up, and raise your heads; for your redemption hath come near," that is, at the time of the kingdom, of which the parable itself treats.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:36
verses.text: "So likewise ye, when ye shall see these things come to pass, know ye that the kingdom of God is nigh at hand".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:37
verses.text: This will be the great day of the Lord, and of the glorious coming of the Son of man from heaven, of which Daniel wrote: "Behold, one like the Son of man came with the clouds of heaven," etc.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:38
verses.text: "And there was given unto Him the kingly power," which (in the parable) "He went away into a far country to receive for Himself," leaving money to His servants wherewithal to trade and get increase—even (that universal kingdom of) all nations, which in the Psalm the Father had promised to give to Him: Ask of me, and I will give Thee the heathen for Thine inheritance".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:39
verses.text: "And all that glory shall serve Him; His dominion shall be an everlasting one, which shall not be taken from Him, and His kingdom that which shall not be destroyed," because in it "men shall not die, neither shall they marry, but be like the angels".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:40
verses.text: It is about the same advent of the Son of man and the benefits thereof that we read in Habakkuk: "Thou wentest forth for the salvation of Thy people, even to save Thine anointed ones,"—in other words, those who shall look up and lift their heads, being redeemed in the time of His kingdom.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:41
verses.text: Since, therefore, these descriptions of the promises, on the one hand, agree together, as do also those of the great catastrophes, on the other—both in the predictions of the prophets and the declarations of the Lord, it will be impossible for you to interpose any distinction between them, as if the catastrophes could be referred to the Creator, as the terrible God, being such as the good god (of Marcion) ought not to permit, much less expect—whilst the promises should be ascribed to the good god, being such as the Creator, in His ignorance of the said god, could not have predicted.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:42
verses.text: If, however, He did predict these promises as His own, since they differ in no respect from the promises of Christ, He will be a match in the freeness of His gifts with the good god himself; and evidently no more will have been promised by your Christ than by my Son of man.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:43
verses.text: (If you examine) the whole passage of this Gospel Scripture, from the inquiry of the disciples down to the parable of the fig-tree you will find the sense in its connection suit in every point the Son of man, so that it consistently ascribes to Him both the sorrows and the joys, and the catastrophes and the promises; nor can you separate them from Him in either respect.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:44
verses.text: For as much, then, as there is but one Son of man whose advent is placed between the two issues of catastrophe and promise, it must needs follow that to that one Son of man belong both the judgments upon the nations, and the prayers of the saints.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:45
verses.text: He who thus comes in midway so as to be common to both issues, will terminate one of them by inflicting judgment on the nations at His coming; and will at the same time commence the other by fulfilling the prayers of His saints: so that if (on the one hand) you grant that the coming of the Son of man is (the advent) of my Christ, then, when you ascribe to Him the infliction of the judgments which precede His appearance, you are compelled also to assign to Him the blessings which issue from the same.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:46
verses.text: If (on the other hand) you will have it that it is the coming of your Christ, then, when you ascribe to him the blessings which are to be the result of his advent, you are obliged to impute to him likewise the infliction of the evils which precede his appearance.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:47
verses.text: For the evils which precede, and the blessings which immediately follow, the coming of the Son of man, are both alike indissolubly connected with that event.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:48
verses.text: Consider, therefore, which of the two Christs you choose to place in the person of the Son of man, to whom you may refer the execution of the two dispensations.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:49
verses.text: You make either the Creator a most beneficent God, or else your own god terrible in his nature! Reflect, in short, on the picture presented in the parable: "Behold the fig-tree, and all the trees; when they produce their fruit, men know that summer is at hand.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:50
verses.text: So likewise ye, when ye see these things come to pass, know ye that the kingdom of God is very near".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:51
verses.text: Now, if the fructification of the common trees be an antecedent sign of the approach of summer, so in like manner do the great conflicts of the world indicate the arrival of that kingdom which they precede.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:52
verses.text: But every sign is His, to whom belong the thing of which it is the sign; and to everything is appointed its sign by Him to whom the thing belongs.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:53
verses.text: If, therefore, these tribulations are the signs of the kingdom, just as the maturity of the trees is of the summer, it follows that the kingdom is the Creator's to whom are ascribed the tribulations which are the signs of the kingdom.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:54
verses.text: Since the beneficent Deity had premised that these things must needs come to pass, although so terrible and dreadful, as they had been predicted by the law and the prophets, therefore He did not destroy the law and the prophets, when He affirmed that what had been foretold therein must be certainly fulfilled.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:55
verses.text: He further declares, "that heaven and earth shall not pass away till all things be fulfilled".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:56
verses.text: What things, pray, are these? Are they the things which the Creator made? Then the elements will tractably endure the accomplishment of their Maker's dispensation.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:57
verses.text: If, however, they emanate from your excellent god, I much doubt whether the heaven and earth will peaceably allow the completion of things which their Creator's enemy has determined! If the Creator quietly submits to this, then He is no "jealous God".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:58
verses.text: But let heaven and earth pass away, since their Lord has so determined; only let His word remain for evermore! And so Isaiah predicted that it should.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:59
verses.text: Let the disciples also be warned, "lest their hearts be overcharged with surfeiting and drunkenness, and cares of this world; and so that day come upon them unawares, like a snare"—if indeed they should forget God amidst the abundance and occupation of the world.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:60
verses.text: Like this will be found the admonition of Moses,—so that He who delivers from "the snare" of that day is none other than He who so long before addressed to men the same admonition.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:61
verses.text: Some places there were in Jerusalem where to teach; other places outside Jerusalem whither to retire—"in the day-time He was teaching in the temple;" just as He had foretold by Hosea: "In my house did they find me, and there did I speak with them".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:62
verses.text: "But at night He went out to the Mount of Olives".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:63
verses.text: For thus had Zechariah pointed out: "And His feet shall stand in that day on the Mount of Olives".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:64
verses.text: Fit hours for an audience there also were.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:65
verses.text: "Early in the morning" must they resort to Him, who (having said by Isaiah, "The Lord giveth me the tongue of the learned") added, "He hath appointed me the morning, and hath also given me an ear to hear".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 39:66
verses.text: Now if this is to destroy the prophets, what will it be to fulfil them?.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 40:1
verses.text: How the Steps in the Passion of the Saviour Were Predetermined in Prophecy.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 40:2
verses.text: The Passover.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 40:3
verses.text: The Treachery of Judas.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 40:4
verses.text: The Institution of the Lord's Supper.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 40:5
verses.text: The Docetic Error of Marcion Confuted by the Body and the Blood of the Lord Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 40:6
verses.text: In like manner does He also know the very time it behoved Him to suffer, since the law prefigures His passion.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 40:7
verses.text: Accordingly, of all the festal days of the Jews He chose the passover.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 40:8
verses.text: In this Moses had declared that there was a sacred mystery: "It is the Lord's passover".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 40:9
verses.text: How earnestly, therefore, does He manifest the bent of His soul: "With desire I have desired to eat this passover with you before I suffer".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 40:10
verses.text: What a destroyer of the law was this, who actually longed to keep its passover!  Could it be that He was so fond of Jewish lamb? But was it not because He had to be "led like a lamb to the slaughter; and because, as a sheep before her shearers is dumb, so was He not to open His mouth," that He so profoundly wished to accomplish the symbol of His own redeeming blood? He might also have been betrayed by any stranger, did I not find that even here too He fulfilled a Psalm: "He who did eat bread with me hath lifted up his heel against me".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 40:11
verses.text: And without a price might He have been betrayed.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 40:12
verses.text: For what need of a traitor was there in the case of one who offered Himself to the people openly, and might quite as easily have been captured by force as taken by treachery? This might no doubt have been well enough for another Christ, but would not have been suitable in One who was accomplishing prophecies.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 40:13
verses.text: For it was written, "The righteous one did they sell for silver".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 40:14
verses.text: The very amount and the destination of the money, which on Judas' remorse was recalled from its first purpose of a fee, and appropriated to the purchase of a potter's field, as narrated in the Gospel of Matthew, were clearly foretold by Jeremiah: "And they took the thirty pieces of silver, the price of Him who was valued and gave them for the potter's field".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 40:15
verses.text: When He so earnestly expressed His desire to eat the passover, He considered it His own feast; for it would have been unworthy of God to desire to partake of what was not His own.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 40:16
verses.text: Then, having taken the bread and given it to His disciples, He made it His own body, by saying, "This is my body," that is, the figure of my body.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 40:17
verses.text: A figure, however, there could not have been, unless there were first a veritable body.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 40:18
verses.text: An empty thing, or phantom, is incapable of a figure.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 40:19
verses.text: If, however, (as Marcion might say,) He pretended the bread was His body, because He lacked the truth of bodily substance, it follows that He must have given bread for us.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 40:20
verses.text: It would contribute very well to the support of Marcion's theory of a phantom body, that bread should have been crucified!  But why call His body bread, and not rather (some other edible thing, say) a melon, which Marcion must have had in lieu of a heart!  He did not understand how ancient was this figure of the body of Christ, who said Himself by Jeremiah: "I was like a lamb or an ox that is brought to the slaughter, and I knew not that they devised a device against me, saying, Let us cast the tree upon His bread," which means, of course, the cross upon His body.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 40:21
verses.text: And thus, casting light, as He always did, upon the ancient prophecies, He declared plainly enough what He meant by the bread, when He called the bread His own body.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 40:22
verses.text: He likewise, when mentioning the cup and making the new testament to be sealed "in His blood," affirms the reality of His body.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 40:23
verses.text: For no blood can belong to a body which is not a body of flesh.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 40:24
verses.text: If any sort of body were presented to our view, which is not one of flesh, not being fleshly, it would not possess blood.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 40:25
verses.text: Thus, from the evidence of the flesh, we get a proof of the body, and a proof of the flesh from the evidence of the blood.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 40:26
verses.text: In order, however, that you may discover how anciently wine is used as a figure for blood, turn to Isaiah, who asks, "Who is this that cometh from Edom, from Bosor with garments dyed in red, so glorious in His apparel, in the greatness of his might? Why are thy garments red, and thy raiment as his who cometh from the treading of the full winepress?" The prophetic Spirit contemplates the Lord as if He were already on His way to His passion, clad in His fleshly nature; and as He was to suffer therein, He represents the bleeding condition of His flesh under the metaphor of garments dyed in red, as if reddened in the treading and crushing process of the wine-press, from which the labourers descend reddened with the wine-juice, like men stained in blood.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 40:27
verses.text: Much more clearly still does the book of Genesis foretell this, when (in the blessing of Judah, out of whose tribe Christ was to come according to the flesh) it even then delineated Christ in the person of that patriarch, saying, "He washed His garments in wine, and His clothes in the blood of grapes"—in His garments and clothes the prophecy pointed out his flesh, and His blood in the wine.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 40:28
verses.text: Thus did He now consecrate His blood in wine, who then (by the patriarch) used the figure of wine to describe His blood.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 41:1
verses.text: The Woe Pronounced on the Traitor a Judicial Act, Which Disproves Christ to Be Such as Marcion Would Have Him to Be.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 41:2
verses.text: Christ's Conduct Before the Council Explained.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 41:3
verses.text: Christ Even Then Directs the Minds of His Judges to the Prophetic Evidences of His Own Mission.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 41:4
verses.text: The Moral Responsibility of These Men Asserted.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 41:5
verses.text: "Woe," says He, "to that man by whom the Son of man is betrayed!" Now it is certain that in this woe must be understood the imprecation and threat of an angry and incensed Master, unless Judas was to escape with impunity after so vast a sin.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 41:6
verses.text: If he were meant to escape with impunity, the "woe" was an idle word; if not, he was of course to be punished by Him against whom he had committed the sin of treachery.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 41:7
verses.text: Now, if He knowingly permitted the man, whom He deliberately elected to be one of His companions, to plunge into so great a crime, you must no longer use an argument against the Creator in Adam's case, which may now recoil on your own God: either that he was ignorant, and had no foresight to hinder the future sinner; or that he was unable to hinder him, even if he was ignorant; or else that he was unwilling, even if he had the foreknowledge and the ability; and so deserved the stigma of maliciousness, in having permitted the man of his own choice to perish in his sin.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 41:8
verses.text: I advise you therefore (willingly) to acknowledge the Creator in that god of yours, rather than against your will to be assimilating your excellent god to Him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 41:9
verses.text: For in the case of Peter, too, he gives you proof that he is a jealous God, when he destined the apostle, after his presumptuous protestations of zeal, to a flat denial of him, rather than prevent his fall.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 41:10
verses.text: The Christ of the prophets was destined, moreover, to be betrayed with a kiss, for He was the Son indeed of Him who was "honoured with the lips" by the people.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 41:11
verses.text: When led before the council, He is asked whether He is the Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 41:12
verses.text: Of what Christ could the Jews have inquired but their own? Why, therefore, did He not, even at that moment, declare to them the rival (Christ)? You reply, In order that He might be able to suffer.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 41:13
verses.text: In other words, that this most excellent god might plunge men into crime, whom he was still keeping in ignorance.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 41:14
verses.text: But even if he had told them, he would yet have to suffer.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 41:15
verses.text: For he said, "If I tell you, ye will not believe".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 41:16
verses.text: And refusing to believe, they would have continued to insist on his death.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 41:17
verses.text: And would he not even more probably still have had to suffer, if had announced himself as sent by the rival god, and as being, therefore, the enemy of the Creator? It was not, then, in order that He might suffer, that He at that critical moment refrained from proclaiming Himself the other Christ, but because they wanted to extort a confession from His mouth, which they did not mean to believe even if He had given it to them, whereas it was their bounden duty to have acknowledged Him in consequence of His works, which were fulfilling their Scriptures.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 41:18
verses.text: It was thus plainly His course to keep Himself at that moment unrevealed, because a spontaneous recognition was due to Him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 41:19
verses.text: But yet for all this, He with a solemn gesture says, "Hereafter shall the Son of man sit on the right hand of the power of God".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 41:20
verses.text: For it was on the authority of the prophecy of Daniel that He intimated to them that He was "the Son of man," and of David's Psalm, that He would "sit at the right hand of God".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 41:21
verses.text: Accordingly, after He had said this, and so suggested a comparison of the Scripture, a ray of light did seem to show them whom He would have them understand Him to be; for they say: "Art thou then the Son of God?" Of what God, but of Him whom alone they knew? Of what God but of Him whom they remembered in the Psalm as having said to His Son, "Sit Thou on my right hand?" Then He answered, "Ye say that I am;" as if He meant: It is ye who say this—not I.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 41:22
verses.text: But at the same time He allowed Himself to be all that they had said, in this their second question.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 41:23
verses.text: By what means, however, are you going to prove to us that they pronounced the sentence "Ergo tu filius Dei es" interrogatively, and not affirmatively? Just as, (on the one hand,) because He had shown them in an indirect manner, by passages of Scripture, that they ought to regard Him as the Son of God, they therefore meant their own words, "Thou art then the Son of God," to be taken in a like (indirect) sense, as much as to say, "You do not wish to say this of yourself plainly," so, (on the other hand,) He likewise answered them, "Ye say that I am," in a sense equally free from doubt, even affirmatively; and so completely was His statement to this effect, that they insisted on accepting that sense which His statement indicated.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 42:1
verses.text: Other Incidents of the Passion Minutely Compared with Prophecy.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 42:2
verses.text: Pilate and Herod.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 42:3
verses.text: Barabbas Preferred to Jesus.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 42:4
verses.text: Details of the Crucifixion.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 42:5
verses.text: The Earthquake and the Mid-Day Darkness.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 42:6
verses.text: All Wonderfully Foretold in the Scriptures of the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 42:7
verses.text: Christ's Giving Up the Ghost No Evidence of Marcion's Docetic Opinions.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 42:8
verses.text: In His Sepulture There is a Refutation Thereof.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 42:9
verses.text: For when He was brought before Pilate, they proceeded to urge Him with the serious charge, of declaring Himself to be Christ the King; that is, undoubtedly, as the Son of God, who was to sit at God's right hand.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 42:10
verses.text: They would, however, have burdened Him with some other title, if they had been uncertain whether He had called Himself the Son of God—if He had not pronounced the words, "Ye say that I am," so as (to admit) that He was that which they said He was.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 42:11
verses.text: Likewise, when Pirate asked Him, "Art thou Christ (the King)?" He answered, as He had before (to the Jewish council) "Thou sayest that I am" in order that He might not seem to have been driven by a fear of his power to give him a fuller answer.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 42:12
verses.text: "And so the Lord hath stood on His trial".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 42:13
verses.text: And he placed His people on their trial.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 42:14
verses.text: The Lord Himself comes to a trial with "the elders and rulers of the people," as Isaiah predicted.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 42:15
verses.text: And then He fulfilled all that had been written of His passion.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 42:16
verses.text: At that time "the heathen raged, and the people imagined vain things; the kings of the earth set themselves, and the rulers gathered themselves together against the Lord and against His Christ".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 42:17
verses.text: The heathen were Pilate and the Romans; the people were the tribes of Israel; the kings were represented in Herod, and the rulers in the chief priests.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 42:18
verses.text: When, indeed, He was sent to Herod gratuitously by Pilate, the words of Hosea were accomplished, for he had prophesied of Christ: "And they shall carry Him bound as a present to the king".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 42:19
verses.text: Herod was "exceeding glad" when he saw Jesus, but he heard not a word from Him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 42:20
verses.text: For, "as a lamb before the shearer is dumb, so He opened not His mouth," because "the Lord had given to Him a disciplined tongue, that he might know how and when it behoved Him to speak"—even that "tongue which clove to His jaws," as the Psalm said it should, through His not speaking.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 42:21
verses.text: Then Barabbas, the most abandoned criminal, is released, as if he were the innocent man; while the most righteous Christ is delivered to be put to death, as if he were the murderer.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 42:22
verses.text: Moreover two malefactors are crucified around Him, in order that He might be reckoned amongst the transgressors.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 42:23
verses.text: Although His raiment was, without doubt, parted among the soldiers, and partly distributed by lot, yet Marcion has erased it all (from his Gospel), for he had his eye upon the Psalm: "They parted my garments amongst them, and cast lots upon my vesture".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 42:24
verses.text: You may as well take away the cross itself! But even then the Psalm is not silent concerning it: "They pierced my hands and my feet".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 42:25
verses.text: Indeed, the details of the whole event are therein read: "Dogs compassed me about; the assembly of the wicked enclosed me around.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 42:26
verses.text: All that looked upon me laughed me to scorn; they did shoot out their lips and shake their heads, (saying,) He hoped in God, let Him deliver Him".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 42:27
verses.text: Of what use now is (your tampering with) the testimony of His garments? If you take it as a booty for your false Christ, still all the Psalm (compensates) the vesture of Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 42:28
verses.text: But, behold, the very elements are shaken.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 42:29
verses.text: For their Lord was suffering.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 42:30
verses.text: If, however, it was their enemy to whom all this injury was done, the heaven would have gleamed with light, the sun would have been even more radiant, and the day would have prolonged its course—gladly gazing at Marcion's Christ suspended on his gibbet! These proofs would still have been suitable for me, even if they had not been the subject of prophecy.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 42:31
verses.text: Isaiah says: "I will clothe the heavens with blackness".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 42:32
verses.text: This will be the day, concerning which Amos also writes: And it shall come to pass in that day, saith the Lord, that the sun shall go down at noon and the earth shall be dark in the clear day".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 42:33
verses.text: (At noon) the veil of the temple was rent" by the escape of the cherubim, which "left the daughter of Sion as a cottage in a vineyard, as a lodge in a garden of cucumbers".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 42:34
verses.text: With what constancy has He also, in Psalm xxx.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 42:35
verses.text: , laboured to present to us the very Christ! He calls with a loud voice to the Father, "Into Thine hands I commend my spirit," that even when dying He might expend His last breath in fulfilling the prophets.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 42:36
verses.text: Having said this, He gave up the ghost".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 42:37
verses.text: Who?  Did the spirit give itself up; or the flesh the spirit?  But the spirit could not have breathed itself out.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 42:38
verses.text: That which breathes is one thing, that which is breathed is another.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 42:39
verses.text: If the spirit is breathed it must needs be breathed by another.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 42:40
verses.text: If, however, there had been nothing there but spirit, it would be said to have departed rather than expired.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 42:41
verses.text: What, however, breathes out spirit but the flesh, which both breathes the spirit whilst it has it, and breathes it out when it loses it? Indeed, if it was not flesh (upon the cross), but a phantom of flesh (and a phantom is but spirit, and so the spirit breathed its own self out, and departed as it did so), no doubt the phantom departed, when the spirit which was the phantom departed: and so the phantom and the spirit disappeared together, and were nowhere to be seen.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 42:42
verses.text: Nothing therefore remained upon the cross, nothing hung there, after "the giving up of the ghost;" there was nothing to beg of Pilate, nothing to take down from the cross, nothing to wrap in the linen, nothing to lay in the new sepulchre.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 42:43
verses.text: Still it was not nothing that was there.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 42:44
verses.text: What was there, then? If a phantom Christ was yet there.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 42:45
verses.text: If Christ had departed, He had taken away the phantom also.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 42:46
verses.text: The only shift left to the impudence of the heretics, is to admit that what remained there was the phantom of a phantom! But what if Joseph knew that it was a body which he treated with so much piety? That same Joseph "who had not consented" with the Jews in their crime? The "happy man who walked not in the counsel of the ungodly, nor stood in the way of sinners, nor sat in the seat of the scornful".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 43:1
verses.text: Conclusions.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 43:2
verses.text: Jesus as the Christ of the Creator Proved from the Events of the Last Chapter of St.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 43:3
verses.text: Luke.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 43:4
verses.text: The Pious Women at the Sepulchre.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 43:5
verses.text: The Angels at the Resurrection.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 43:6
verses.text: The Manifold Appearances of Christ After the Resurrection.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 43:7
verses.text: His Mission of the Apostles Amongst All Nations.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 43:8
verses.text: All Shown to Be in Accordance with the Wisdom of the Almighty Father, as Indicated in Prophecy.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 43:9
verses.text: The Body of Christ After Death No Mere Phantom.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 43:10
verses.text: Marcion's Manipulation of the Gospel on This Point.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 43:11
verses.text: It was very meet that the man who buried the Lord should thus be noticed in prophecy, and thenceforth be "blessed;" since prophecy does not omit the (pious) office of the women who resorted before day-break to the sepulchre with the spices which they had prepared.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 43:12
verses.text: For of this incident it is said by Hosea: "To seek my face they will watch till day-light, saying unto me, Come, and let us return to the Lord: for He hath taken away, and He will heal us; He hath smitten, and He will bind us up; after two days will He revive us: in the third day He will raise us up".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 43:13
verses.text: For who can refuse to believe that these words often revolved in the thought of those women between the sorrow of that desertion with which at present they seemed to themselves to have been smitten by the Lord, and the hope of the resurrection itself, by which they rightly supposed that all would be restored to them? But when "they found not the body (of the Lord Jesus)," "His sepulture was removed from the midst of them," according to the prophecy of Isaiah.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 43:14
verses.text: "Two angels however, appeared there".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 43:15
verses.text: For just so many honorary companions were required by the word of God, which usually prescribes "two witnesses".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 43:16
verses.text: Moreover, the women, returning from the sepulchre, and from this vision of the angels, were foreseen by Isaiah, when he says, "Come, ye women, who return from the vision;" that is, "come," to report the resurrection of the Lord.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 43:17
verses.text: It was well, however, that the unbelief of the disciples was so persistent, in order that to the last we might consistently maintain that Jesus revealed Himself to the disciples as none other than the Christ of the prophets.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 43:18
verses.text: For as two of them were taking a walk, and when the Lord had joined their company, without its appearing that it was He, and whilst He dissembled His knowledge of what had just taken place, they say: "But we trusted that it had been He which should have redeemed Israel,"—meaning their own, that is, the Creator's Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 43:19
verses.text: So far had He been from declaring Himself to them as another Christ! They could not, however, deem Him to be the Christ of the Creator; nor, if He was so deemed by them, could He have tolerated this opinion concerning Himself, unless He were really He whom He was supposed to be.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 43:20
verses.text: Otherwise He would actually be the author of error, and the prevaricator of truth, contrary to the character of the good God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 43:21
verses.text: But at no time even after His resurrection did He reveal Himself to them as any other than what, on their own showing, they had always thought Him to be.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 43:22
verses.text: He pointedly reproached them: "O fools, and slow of heart in not believing that which He spake unto you".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 43:23
verses.text: By saying this, He proves that He does not belong to the rival god, but to the same God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 43:24
verses.text: For the same thing was said by the angels to the women: "Remember how He spake unto you when He was yet in Galilee, saying, The Son of man must be delivered up, and be crucified, and on the third day rise again".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 43:25
verses.text: "Must be delivered up;" and why, except that it was so written by God the Creator? He therefore upbraided them, because they were offended solely at His passion, and because they doubted of the truth of the resurrection which had been reported to them by the women, whereby (they showed that) they had not believed Him to have been the very same as they had thought Him to be.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 43:26
verses.text: Wishing, therefore, to be believed by them in this wise, He declared Himself to be just what they had deemed Him to be—the Creator's Christ, the Redeemer of Israel.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 43:27
verses.text: But as touching the reality of His body, what can be plainer? When they were doubting whether He were not a phantom—nay, were supposing that He was one—He says to them, "Why are ye troubled, and why do thoughts arise in your hearts? See my hands and my feet, that it is I myself; for a spirit hath not bones, as ye see me have".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 43:28
verses.text: Now Marcion was unwilling to expunge from his Gospel some statements which even made against him—I suspect, on purpose, to have it in his power from the passages which he did not suppress, when he could have done so, either to deny that he had expunged anything, or else to justify his suppressions, if he made any.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 43:29
verses.text: But he spares only such passages as he can subvert quite as well by explaining them away as by expunging them from the text.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 43:30
verses.text: Thus, in the passage before us, he would have the words, "A spirit hath not bones, as ye see me have," so transposed, as to mean, "A spirit, such as ye see me to be, hath not bones;" that is to say, it is not the nature of a spirit to have bones.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 43:31
verses.text: But what need of so tortuous a construction, when He might have simply said, "A spirit hath not bones, even as you observe that I have not?"  Why, moreover, does He offer His hands and His feet for their examination—limbs which consist of bones—if He had no bones? Why, too, does He add, "Know that it is I myself," when they had before known Him to be corporeal?  Else, if He were altogether a phantom, why did He upbraid them for supposing Him to be a phantom? But whilst they still believed not, He asked them for some meat, for the express purpose of showing them that He had teeth.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 43:32
verses.text: And now, as I would venture to believe, we have accomplished our undertaking.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 43:33
verses.text: We have set forth Jesus Christ as none other than the Christ of the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 43:34
verses.text: Our proofs we have drawn from His doctrines, maxims, affections, feelings, miracles, sufferings, and even resurrection—as foretold by the prophets.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 43:35
verses.text: Even to the last He taught us (the same truth of His mission), when He sent forth His apostles to preach His gospel "among all nations;" for He thus fulfilled the psalm: "Their sound is gone out through all the earth, and their words to the end of the world".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 43:36
verses.text: Marcion, I pity you; your labour has been in vain.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book IV 43:37
verses.text: For the Jesus Christ who appears in your Gospel is mine.
